page.title: History of the Indian cricket team

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} The [[Indian cricket team]] made its [[Test cricket]] debut in 1931 and has since advanced to be among the top four test teams in the [[ICC Test Championship|ICC rankings]] in each of 2005 to 2008.<ref>ICC website: [http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/rankings/rankings-test-2005.html 2005] [http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/rankings/rankings-test-2006.html 2006] [http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/rankings/rankings-test-2007.html 2007] [http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/rankings/rankings-test-2008.html 2008]</ref> The team won the [[One Day International|ODI]] [[Cricket World Cup]] in [[1983 Cricket World Cup|1983]] and [[2011 Cricket World Cup|2011]]. In other major International victories, Team India won the inaugural [[ICC World Twenty20|Twenty20 World Cup]] in [[2007 ICC World Twenty20|2007]] and [[ICC Champions Trophy]] in [[2013 ICC Champions Trophy|2013]].
==Pre-independence== :''See also: [[History of cricket in India to 1918]], [[List of Indian Test cricketers]] and [[List of Indian ODI cricketers]]'' [[Image:Ranjitsinh.jpeg|thumb|120px|right|Kumar Shri Ranjitsinhji was an Indian who played for the English cricket team]] A few Indians played as members of the [[English cricket team]] while India was under [[British India|British rule]], including [[Ranjitsinhji]] and [[KS Duleepsinhji]], but India made its debut as a Test-cricket-playing-nation in England in 1932 led by [[CK Nayudu]], well before [[Partition of India|Indian independence]]. The team performed well, with [[Mohammad Nissar]] taking 5-93 and 1-42 in the match against England.<!--non-cricket playing nation's readers wont understand 5-93 and 1-42. for conceding 93 etc, or wikilink to where this pattern of score is explained.--> The match was given test status despite being only 3 days in length. England, batting first, scored 258 with Nissar cleaning up the openers and tailenders. However the Indian team failed to capitalize on their bowling performance, all out for 189 with [[CK Nayudu]] the top scorer with 40 runs. England went on to score 275 and set India a target of 346, which always seemed out of the visitor's grasp. India were all out for 187 and lost by 158 runs.
The team's first series as an independent country was in 1948 against [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] at [[Brisbane]]. Australia were led by [[Sir Don Bradman]] while India was led by [[Lala Amarnath]]. The Australians returned home, winning the 5 Test series with the score 4-0.
==Post Independence== India's first ever Test victory came against England at [[Chennai|Madras]] in 1952. India's first series victory was against [[Pakistani cricket team|Pakistan]] later the same year. In 1954, India drew a 5-Test series with Pakistan 0-0, the batting strength from India had come from [[Polly Umrigar]] and [[Vijay Manjrekar]] while the prime bowler was [[Subhash Gupte]] with 21 wickets in the series. India's first series against [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]] in 1956 created a comprehensive series victory for India, winning the 5-Test series 2-0. [[MH Mankad]] was excellent in his batting, averaging 105.2 in the series while scoring 526 runs. Once again, S.M. Gupte held India's bowling together, with 34 wickets. The remainder of the 1950s did not show as good results as the start: India lost a 3-Test series to Australia (2-0), lost a 5-Test series against the [[West Indian cricket team|West Indies]] (3-0),
The team's performances again began to improve in the 1960s, starting with their first series win over England in 1961-62. During this time, India's strong record at home started to develop, in which the team won a series against New Zealand in 1965-66 and drew series against Pakistan, Australia and England. In 1967-68, India won their first series outside the subcontinent against New Zealand.
[[Sunil Gavaskar]] made his debut for India in the West Indies in 1970-71 and immediately made an impact, scoring a total of 774 runs for the series and helping India to a 1-0 series win, their first ever win over the West Indies. Together with established players like [[Bishen Bedi]], [[Srinivas Venkataraghavan]], [[Erapalli Prasanna]] and [[Bhagwat Chandrasekhar]], Gavaskar formed the nucleus of arguably India's strongest Test team up to that point in time. India's win over the West Indies was followed by home and away wins over England in 1971 and 1972-73.
During the 1980s, other players like [[Mohammed Azharuddin]], [[Ravi Shastri]], [[Laxman Sivaramakrishnan]], [[Sanjay Manjrekar]], [[Krish Srikkanth]] and [[Maninder Singh (cricketer)|Maninder Singh]] emerged. India won the [[Cricket World Cup]] in 1983, defeating [[West Indian cricket team|West Indies]] in an exciting final. In 1985, India won the World Championship of Cricket in Australia. The Test series victory in 1986 in England remained, for nearly 19 years, the last Test series win outside [[Indian subcontinent|subcontinent]]. Sunil Gavaskar became the first batsman to accumulate 10,000 runs in Test cricket, and went on to register a record 34 centuries, surpassed only recently by [[Sachin Tendulkar]]. [[Kapil Dev]], a genuine all-rounder, became the highest wicket taker in Test cricket, surpassing [[Richard Hadlee]] to take a total of 434 wickets, a record which has since been broken by [[Courtney Walsh]], [[Shane Warne]] and [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] and has also been surpassed by fellow Indian [[Anil Kumble]]. [[Image:Sachin at Castrol Golden Spanner Awards.jpg|thumb|Sachin Tendulkar, India's leading run-scorer in Test and ODI cricket.]] The emergence of Sachin Tendulkar and [[Anil Kumble]] in 1989 and 1990 was to herald an era of Indian cricket that was dominated by stars and individual brilliance. Sachin Tendulkar became arguably the best batsman in the world, along with [[Brian Lara]] of the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] and in 1998, Sir Donald Bradman himself remarked that Tendulkar batting style was similar to his. [[Mohammed Azharuddin]], who captained India for most of the 1990s, proved a captain whose main strength, if not his motivational skills, was an ability to stay cool under pressure. Azharuddin's artistic batting however declined during the later years of his captaincy, and his best innings during this time were mostly when playing at home. The [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabadi]] stylist's career ended after 99 Tests when he was banned for life after being implicated in the [[match-fixing]] scandal. Under his captaincy, the Indian team became virtually unbeatable at home, with big wins against teams such as England, Sri Lanka, South Africa and Australia. Their performances abroad, however, left a lot to be desired.
Towards the end of 1999, the Indian team was in flux. Although they had performed well in the [[1999 Cricket World Cup|1999 World Cup]], the winter was marked by a disastrous tour to Australia which exposed the Indian team's weaknesses when playing abroad, marked with a loss of form of most of the batsmen, except Tendulkar and the newly emerged [[VVS Laxman]]. After Tendulkar quit captaincy and Azharuddin was banned for match-fixing, Saurav Ganguly took over as captain, and the New Zealander [[John Wright (cricketer)|John Wright]] became coach.
Ganguly's captaincy heralded a new era in Indian cricket. It began in the famous series against Australia in 2001, when [[Steve Waugh]]'s strong team was defeated 2-1 in a Test series after having taken a 1-0 lead at [[Mumbai]]. The series is best known for a remarkable turnaround by the Indian team in the [[Kolkata]] Test, when VVS Laxman, Rahul Dravid and [[Harbhajan Singh]]'s performance took India to victory after they had [[follow-on|followed on]]. This series marked a turning point in the Indian team's fortunes, and provided the team with the boost they dearly needed. This was followed by stellar performances by the team when playing abroad, with Test victories coming in Zimbabwe, Sri Lanka, West Indies, England, Australia, and a famous series victory against arch-rivals Pakistan in 2004. The series in England in 2002 is billed as Rahul Dravid's series, as he became the top scorer for the Indians, with centuries coming at [[Trent Bridge]] in [[Nottingham]], [[Headingley Stadium|Headingley]] in [[Leeds]] and a famous 217 at the [[The Oval|Oval]] in [[London]]. This was followed by a sensational win in Australia at [[Adelaide]] in 2003, where Dravid, VVS Laxman and [[Ajit Agarkar]] scripted a come-from-behind victory after the team had conceded 556 runs in the first innings. The series win in Pakistan that followed was marked by [[Virender Sehwag]] becoming the first Indian to score a triple century in Test cricket. Along with Sehwag, players like [[Yuvraj Singh]] and [[Mohammed Kaif]] emerged, making the Indian batting order one of the strongest in the world in both forms of the game*. Their performances helped reduced India's dependence on their top guns in one-day cricket, and a 7-batsman policy contributed to India's successes in the limited-overs game, culminating in their reaching the final of the [[2003 Cricket World Cup]]. In the bowling department, India unearthed a plethora of fast-bowling talent, with [[Zaheer Khan]], [[Ashish Nehra]], and later [[Irfan Pathan]] and [[L Balaji]] leading the pack. The veteran Anil Kumble became the highest wicket-taker for India after surpassing Kapil Dev, and also passed the 500-mark in March 2006. His bowling performances abroad improved considerably, and he played a major part in India's overseas performances in England, Australia and Pakistan. Harbhajan Singh also provided him great company in the spin department, and at home the two bowling in tandem became a familiar sight.
* [[Rahul Dravid]], [[Sachin Tendulkar]] and [[Virender Sehwag]] were selected to play for the [[2005 ICC Super Series|ICC World XI]] in the 2005 "[[ICC Super Series|SuperTest]]" against Australia.
In 2005, Indian cricket was again shrouded in controversy. After a somewhat slow season marked by a dip in team performance following the famous Pakistan series ended, the coaching job passed from John Wright to the Australian [[Greg Chappell]]. Saurav Ganguly, whose batting form had taken a beating in that year, was involved in a spat with Chappell over whether he should be continuing as captain to reduce pressure on him. This was followed by Ganguly being dropped from the team and Rahul Dravid taking over as captain. While Tendulkar, Sehwag and Dravid formed the mainstay of the Indian batting, the coming of age of players like Yuvraj Singh and Mohammad Kaif led to the emergence of younger stars like [[Suresh Raina]] and [[MS Dhoni]]. India, however have always struggled in the pace department with the only prominent pace bowler ever coming was [[Zaheer Khan]]
Dravid's captaincy was cut short in the ill-fated 2007 World Cup, where India were out of the league stage following an embarrassing loss to Bangladesh. This was followed by Mahendra Singh Dhoni taking over the reins. Under MS Dhoni, India won the inaugural T20 World cup. It also began an era of India's dominance in world cricket in both tests and ODIs, culminating in a victory in the 2011 Cricket World Cup and a 4-0 whitewash of Australia in a home test series.<ref>http://www.espncricinfo.com/icc_cricket_worldcup2011/engine/current/match/433606.html</ref> It also saw Indian batsmen scoring the only 200s ever, first Sachin Tendulkar then Virender Sehwag and then [[Rohit Sharma]] on three occasions. Dhoni has been widely acknowledged as the most successful Indian captain ever. However, following a drubbing in a test series down under in late 2014, he retired from tests.
==International Tournaments== {{see also|India at the Cricket World Cup}} Since advancing to full Test Status and the creation of more and more international cricket tournaments, India has slowly become involved in a number of Cricketing tournament's including the [[Cricket World Cup]], [[ICC Champions Trophy]] and [[Asia Cup]]. India's first two [[Cricket World Cup]]s were largely failures, and the team failed to progress beyond the first round. But India upset the West Indies in the final of the [[1983 Cricket World Cup]] to claim the Prudential Cricket World Cup for the first time, captained by Kapil Dev. India and the West Indies had cruised through the preliminary rounds in Group B, while England and Pakistan emerged the victors from Group A. Most considered India to be the underdogs in the group stages, and their win against West Indies was categorized as similar to Zimbabwe's win over Australia in the same World Cup. They were, in fact, quoted as having odds of 66 to 1 before the beginning of the tournament.
India's performance in the remaining world cups has been considerably consistent. In the [[1987 Cricket World Cup]], the team advanced to the semi-finals as favourites, they did the same in 1996, both times they suffered upset defeats in the semi-finals. India was less strong in the [[1999 Cricket World Cup]], and did not make it past the Super Six section. However they impressed all in the [[2003 Cricket World Cup|2003 Cup]], only losing two games (both against reigning champions [[Australia]]) and advancing to the finals before taking a loss.
In the year after their World Cup victory, (1984) India continued its new-found dominance over One Day Cricket with a comprehensive win over arch-rivals [[Pakistan cricket team|Pakistan]] in the final. They went on to secure more victories over their Asian rivals, winning the 1984 [[Asia Cup]] with a victory over [[Sri Lankan cricket team|Sri Lanka]] in the finals. It won its third consecutive Asia Cup with a victory over Sri Lanka in 1990. It continued its strong streak in 1995, again beating Sri Lanka in the final. However, in 1997, a confident Sri Lanka riding on their first-ever World Cup victory swept past a weaker Indian side, breaking the 4-tournament winning streak.
==Recent history== India's traditional strengths have always been its line-up of [[spin bowling|spin bowlers]] and [[batsman|batsmen]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://content-www1.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/260862.html|title = India can find the right balance before the world cup|work = Jamie Alter|publisher = http://www.cricinfo.com/|accessdate = 14 October 2006}} Gavaskar: ''I would imagine that the spinners have always been our strength''</ref> Currently, it has a very strong batting lineup with [[Rahul Dravid]], [[Sachin Tendulkar]] and [[Virender Sehwag]] all being selected to play for the [[2005 ICC Super Series|ICC World XI]] in the 2005 "[[ICC Super Series|SuperTest]]" against Australia. In previous times, India was unique in that it was the only country to regularly field three spinners in one team, whereas one is the norm, and of the fifteen players to have taken more than 100 wickets, only four were pace bowlers from the last 20 years.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www1.cricinfo.com/db/STATS/IND/BOWLING/TEST_BOWL_MOST_WKTS_IND.html | title = India - Test Career Bowling - Most Wickets | work = Cricinfo | publisher = http://www.cricinfo.com/ | accessdate = 26 October 2006 }}</ref> However, in recent years, Indian pace bowling has improved, with the emerging talents of [[Irfan Pathan]], [[Munaf Patel]] and [[Sreesanth]] and many more playing in the national team.
[[Image:Wankhede-1.JPG|thumb|The Indian cricket team in action in the Wankhede Stadium]] Historically, the Indian team has not performed as well overseas as it has in India. Since the year 2000, the Indian team underwent major improvements under the guidance of coach [[John Wright (cricketer)|John Wright]] and captain [[Saurav Ganguly]]. The team drew a Test series with Australia in [[Australia]], which is usually considered a tough tour. It was followed by a historic Test and ODI series win against arch-rivals Pakistan while playing in Pakistan.
India has had a very good record against Australia and, before the 2004/05 tour, never being defeated by Australia in a Test Series in India since 1969. This was the reason for [[Australian national cricket captains|Australian captain]] [[Steve Waugh]] labelling India as the "Final Frontier".<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/NATIONAL/IND/NEWS/STEVEWAUGH_COLUMN.html|title = Steve Waugh Column|work = Steve Waugh|publisher = http://www.cricinfo.com/|accessdate = 21 September 2006}}</ref> The famous 2001 Australian tour of India saw [[Harbhajan Singh]] become the first Indian to take a Test hat-trick and started a good run for the team, as India beat Australia 2-1. India also came runners up to Australia in the final of the [[2003 Cricket World Cup]].
Since 2004, India had not been doing as well in One-day Internationals. The players who took India to great heights over the past ten years such as Sachin Tendulkar, Sourav Ganguly and Anil Kumble grew older and did not maintain their form and fitness. Following the series loss to Australia, India collapsed on the final day in the Third Test in [[Bangalore]] in early 2005 against Pakistan to squander a series victory, and then lost four consecutive ODIs against Pakistan. This was exacerbated by the suspension handed to captain Ganguly for slow over-rates. [[Greg Chappell]] took over from John Wright as the new coach of the Indian cricket team following the series, and replaced Kumble and [[V. V. S. Laxman]] from the ODI team with younger players. India's unconvincing ODI form continued, scraping past a West Indian team depleted by industrial action in the [[2005 Indian Oil Cup]] and a similarly depleted Zimbabwean team only to be defeated twice in the finals by New Zealand, continuing a poor ODI finals record.
The tension resulted in a fallout between Chappell and Ganguly lead to a confidential email sent by Chappell to the BCCI being leaked, in which he condemned the leadership and performance of Ganguly. After a series of high-profile board meetings and public jousting including some players, [[Rahul Dravid]] was installed as the captain, triggering a revival in the team's fortunes. The Indians subsequently defeated Sri Lanka 6-1 in a home series. An important part about this series was the discovery of the young talent of the team, including [[Mahendra Singh Dhoni]], [[Suresh Raina]], [[Gautam Gambhir]] and [[Irfan Pathan]]. The team also beat the Sri Lankans in the Test series 2-0 to displace England from its position in second place in the ICC Test rankings, but India slipped back by losing the high-profile<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.hinduonnet.com/2005/03/02/stories/2005030204681900.htm|title = TWI gets production rights for India-Pakistan series|work = The Hindu - Sport|publisher = http://www.hinduonnet.com/|accessdate = 14 October 2006}}</ref> series to [[Pakistan]]. Indian team continued its good form in ODIs, beating [[Pakistan]] 4-1 in Pakistan. India achieved the world-record of winning 17 successive matches chasing the total. India convincingly won [[England]]'s tour of [[India]] winning the series 5-1. After leveling the DLF Cup series 1-1 in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[India]] travelled to [[West Indies]] where they lost the ODI series 1-4 to a weak West Indies team which was ranked 8th in the ICC ODI Ranking. The series loss again questioned the Indian team's ability to play away from the Sub-continent and the chances of the Indian team to win the [[2007 Cricket World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.hinduonnet.com/2005/03/02/stories/2005030204681900.htm|title = India can find right balance before World Cup|work = Jamie Alter|publisher = http://www.cricinfo.com/|accessdate = 14 October 2006}}</ref> The Indian team later clinched the Test series against West Indies 1-0, the first Indian series win in the Caribbean since 1989. For the statistics of [[Indian national cricket team|Indian cricket team]] after [[2011 Cricket World Cup|2011 world cup]], watch [[Indian cricket performance from 2011|Indian cricket from 2011]]. Recently the Indian Cricket team has beaten the Australian cricket team with an impressive 2-1 victory in the 2017 Border-Gavaskar trophy, also it beat Bangladesh in the one-off test which was also Bangladesh's maiden tour of India. Before, India beat England by 4-0 in the 2016-17 Antony De Mello Trophy in the 5 match test series.
In June 2017, [[India national cricket team|India]] toured England for the [[2017 ICC Champions Trophy]] where the [[Virat Kohli]] led mighty team lost to [[Pakistan]] in the final by 180 runs. Later India toured the [[West Indies national cricket team|Windies]] where the team won the [[One Day International|ODI]] series by 3-1 but lost the [[Twenty20 International|T20I]] series. By defeating [[Sri Lanka]] by 9-0 in all three formats, India became the first team to cleansweep Sri Lanka in [[One Day International|ODI]] series in their home soil.
In January 2018, [[Virat Kohli]] led Indian team toured South Africa where they lost the Test series by 1-2. But the Team showed some extravagant skills and defeated the mighty South African team and clinched the [[One Day International|ODI]] series by 5-1 and [[Twenty20 International|T20I]] series by 2-1. By the series win, India became the second Asian country to defeat South Africa in [[One Day International|ODI]] and [[Twenty20 International|T20I]] series on their home soil after [[Pakistan]].

Basketball: 18,336;

Theatre at the Honda Center: 8,400 | dimensions = {{convert|650000|sqft|m2}} | publictransit = {{rint|us|amtrak}} {{rint|losangeles|metrolink}} [[Anaheim Regional Transportation Intermodal Center|Anaheim]] }} The '''Honda Center''' (formerly known as the '''Arrowhead Pond of Anaheim''') is an [[indoor arena]] located in [[Anaheim, California]]. The arena is home to the [[Anaheim Ducks]] of the [[National Hockey League]]. Originally named the '''Anaheim Arena''' during construction, it was completed in 1993 at a cost of US$123 million. [[Arrowhead Water]] paid $15 million for the [[naming rights]] over 10 years in October 1993.[http://www.ovguide.com/honda-center-9202a8c04000641f8000000000343c75 ovguide.com] In the short period of time between the enfranchisement of the [[Anaheim Ducks|Mighty Ducks]] and the naming rights deal with Arrowhead, Disney referred to the Arena as the '''Pond of Anaheim'''.In the 1993–94 Mighty Ducks of Anaheim media guide, Disney and the Ducks organization referred to the arena as the "Pond of Anaheim." This was prior to the naming rights deal with Arrowhead Water. [[Amazon Standard Identification Number|ASIN]]: B001EBD3BM In October 2006, [[Honda]] paid $60 million for the naming rights for over 15 years.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jul/20/sports/sp-pond20 | work=Los Angeles Times | first1=Bill | last1=Shaikin | first2=Greg | last2=Johnson | date=July 20, 2006 | title=Pond to Get a New Name}} ==History== [[Image:Honda-pano2.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A panorama of Honda Center's exterior]] [[Image:Honda-pano.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Panorama of Honda Center's interior before a 2007 playoff hockey game]] [[Image:Honda Center in Anaheim California on 22-03-2008.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Honda Center in its basketball configuration before an NCAA basketball game]] [[Image:New Scoreboard at Honda Center.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The New Scoreboard at Honda Center as seen from Section 438 during the 2016 Stanley Cup Play-offs on April 27, 2016]] The arena opened on June 19, 1993, with a [[Barry Manilow]] concert as its first event. Since then, it has been host to a number of events, such as the [[2003 Stanley Cup Finals|2003]] and [[2007 Stanley Cup Finals]]. On June 6, 2007, the Anaheim Ducks defeated the [[Ottawa Senators]], 6–2, in game five of the Final at Honda Center to clinch the franchise's first Stanley Cup championship.{{fact|date=June 2018}} Honda Center has hosted several [[List of UFC events|UFC events]], starting with [[UFC 59]] in 2006. It hosted the [[2005 IBF World Championships]] for badminton in 2005.{{fact|date=June 2018}} From 1994 to 1998, it served as a second home for the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]'s [[Los Angeles Clippers]]. It was the home arena for the [[Anaheim Bullfrogs]] of [[Roller Hockey International]] from 1994 to 1999 and for the [[Anaheim Piranhas]] of the [[Arena Football League]] from 1996 to 1997.{{fact|date=June 2018}} This arena has also hosted a [[Professional Bull Riders|PBR]] Bud Light Cup (later [[Built Ford Tough Series]]) event annually since 1998. Since 1994, the arena has hosted the annual [[John R. Wooden Classic]].{{fact|date=June 2018}} In 2011, the arena began hosting the [[Big West Conference]] Men's and Women's Basketball tournaments. The arena has also hosted the NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament six times, as the West Regional site – [[1998 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1998]], [[2001 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2001]], [[2003 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2003]], [[2008 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2008]], [[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2011]], [[2014 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2014]] and [[2016 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2016]]. It even hosted the Frozen Four, the semifinals and final of the [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship]], in 1999, underscoring the popularity of hockey in the region. On December 6, 2000, music legend [[Tina Turner]] played her last concert at the arena for the record breaking [[Twenty Four Seven Tour]], but after popular demand, Turner returned to the arena before a sellout crowd on October 14, 2008, for her [[Tina!: 50th Anniversary Tour]]. The Honda Center lies northeast across [[California State Route 57]] from [[Angel Stadium of Anaheim|Angel Stadium]] (where [[Major League Baseball]]'s [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim]] play) and roughly {{convert|3|mi}} from [[Disneyland Park (Anaheim)|Disneyland Park]]. It is also across the street from [[Anaheim Regional Transportation Intermodal Center]] with service by [[Amtrak]] (''[[Pacific Surfliner]]''), [[Metrolink (Southern California)|Metrolink]] (''[[Orange County Line]]''), [[Anaheim Resort Transit]], [[Orange County Transportation Authority]] and private transportation companies. The arena seats up 17,174 for its primary tenant, the Ducks. It takes only five hours to convert Honda Center from a sporting arena to an 8,400-seat amphitheater. There are 84 [[luxury box|luxury suites]] in the building, which has hosted 17.5 million people, as of 2003. In 2005, the arena became the first in the U.S. to have two full levels of 360° ribbon displays installed. [[Daktronics]] of [[Brookings, South Dakota]], designed, manufactured and installed the {{convert|1800|ft|m}} of full-color [[LED]] technology. Outside the venue, the marquee was upgraded with two large video displays measuring {{convert|8|ft|m}} high by {{convert|21|ft|m}}, and a new marquee was built with more [[LED]] video displays.{{cite web |url=http://www.daktronics.com/en-us/photos/details?pn=WP-15256 |title=Daktronics Photo Gallery: Honda Center}} [[Broadcom]] chairman [[Henry Samueli]] owns the company that operates the arena, Anaheim Arena Management, LLC, and the arena's primary tenant, the Ducks, giving him great flexibility in scheduling events and recruiting new tenants. Samueli hopes to bring an [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] team to the arena. In 2015, Samueli purchased the [[Norfolk Admirals (AHL)|Norfolk Admirals]] of the [[American Hockey League]] and, with the AHL incarnation of the Admirals relocating to [[San Diego]] to become the reactivated [[San Diego Gulls]], it is anticipated that Samueli through Anaheim Arena Management will purchase [[Valley View Casino Center]] in that city in time for the 2015–16 AHL season. During the 2014–2015 NHL Season, it was announced that Honda Center would get a new scoreboard that will replace the one that was in place since its opening in 1993. The new scoreboard made its debut in a Ducks Preseason game against the Los Angeles Kings.http://ducks.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=776852 ==Notable events == ===Ice Hockey=== * Games 3, 4, and 6 of the [[2003 Stanley Cup Finals]] * Games 1, 2, and 5 of the [[2007 Stanley Cup Finals]] ===MMA & Pro Wrestling=== *[[Affliction: Banned]] was held in the Honda Center. *[[UFC 59]], [[UFC 63]], [[UFC 76]], [[UFC 121]], [[UFC on Fox 1]], [[UFC 157]] and [[UFC 214]] were held in the Honda Center.{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamania.com/2012/11/14/3643402/ufc-157-location-honda-center-anaheim-ufc-fuel-tv-7-california-mma|title=UFC 157 set for Honda Center in Anaheim|publisher=MMAmania.com|date=2012-11-14|accessdate=2012-11-14|last=Haggerty|first=Kevin}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mmafighting.com/2017/2/24/14731214/ufc-214-in-anaheim-changed-to-july-29|title=UFC 214 in Anaheim changed to July 29|publisher=mmafighting.com|author=Danny Segura|date=2017-02-24|accessdate=2017-04-21}} *The arena has hosted a number of [[WWE]] events including [[WrestleMania XII]], [[Royal Rumble (1999)|Royal Rumble 1999]], [[WrestleMania 2000]]{{cite web|first=John|last=Powell|date=April 2, 2000|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingPPV/apr3_wrestlemania.html|title=WrestleMania 2000 a flop|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|work=Slam! Sports|accessdate=March 16, 2008}}, as well as various episodes of [[WWE Raw|Monday Night Raw]] and [[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown]]. ===Concerts=== Honda Center has the second highest gross ticket sales from special events on the West Coast, following only [[Staples Center]].{{cite journal|last=Casacchia|first=Chris|title=Royal Reach: NBA Team Would Boost Honda Center Business, Bring Challenges|journal=[[Orange County Business Journal]]|date=April 4, 2011|volume=34|issue=14|page=66}} These events have included the following over the years: *[[Barbra Streisand]] recorded the final date here from her first tour in 30 years [[Barbra Streisand in Concert]] in June 1994. *[[Smashing Pumpkins]] performed on December 9th and December 10th in 1996 as part of their [[Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness]] tour. *[[Rock music|Rock]] band [[No Doubt]], natives of Anaheim, recorded their two 1997 concert stops at Honda Center, releasing them as their first concert video, ''[[Live in the Tragic Kingdom]]''. *[[Janet Jackson]] performed for the first time at the arena during her [[The Velvet Rope Tour]] on August 23, 1998. She returned for her [[All for You Tour]] on September 29, 2001. On September 23, 2017, she performed again as part of her [[State of the World Tour]]. *[[TLC (group)|TLC]] performed at the arena on January 10, 2000 during their [[FanMail Tour]]. The tour would be their last as a trio. Band member [[Lisa "Left Eye" Lopes]] was killed in a car accident in April 2002. *[[Britney Spears]] performed on 20 November 2001 during her [[Dream Within a Dream Tour]]. She returned in April 19 and 20, 2009 for her [[The Circus Starring Britney Spears]] and on June 24, 2011 with her [[Femme Fatale Tour]]. *[[KIIS-FM]]'s [[KIIS-FM Jingle Ball|Jingle Ball]] – December 19, 2002, December 3, 2004, December 7, 2006, October 27, 2007 and December 6, 2008 *When No Doubt's lead singer, [[Gwen Stefani]] embarked on a [[solo album|solo]] venture, she filmed her two homecoming concerts at Honda Center in 2005. The [[DVD]] was released as ''[[Harajuku Lovers Live]]''. *[[Mariah Carey]]'s latest [[DVD]] release, entitled ''[[The Adventures of Mimi (DVD)|The Adventures of Mimi]]'' was recorded at the Honda Center on October 8, 2006, during [[The Adventures of Mimi Tour]]. *The [[Jonas Brothers]] recorded the companion album to their 3-D concert movie at the Honda Center. *[[U2]] performed at the arena five times: the first, the second and the third were on April 23, 24 and 26, 2001 during their [[Elevation Tour]], in front of a total sold out crowd of 49,377 people. The fourth and the fifth were on April 1 and 2, 2005 during their [[Vertigo Tour]], in front of a total sold out crowd of 33,535 people. *[[Depeche Mode]] performed at the arena six times: the first and the second were on December 20 and 22, 1998 during their [[The Singles Tour|Singles Tour]]. The third and the fourth were on August 18 and 19, 2001 during their [[Exciter Tour]]. The fifth one was on November 23, 2005 during their [[Touring the Angel]]. The sixth one was on August 19, 2009 during their [[Tour of the Universe (tour)|Tour of the Universe]], in front of a crowd of 12,430 people. The 2009 show was recorded for the group's live albums project ''[[Recording the Universe]]''. *[[K-pop]] artists under [[S.M. Entertainment]] featuring [[BoA]], [[TVXQ]], [[Super Junior]], [[Girls' Generation]], [[Shinee|SHINee]], [[f(x) (band)|f(x)]] and [[EXO (band)|EXO]], performed the first show of their third world tour [[SMTown Live '12 World Tour]] making them the first Korean artists to perform at the arena. The May 20, 2012 show was an instant sell out. [[South Korea]]n TV broadcast network [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC]] filmed and later aired an edited version of the concert.[https://www.facebook.com/notes/smtown/smtown-live-world-tour-%E2%85%A2-to-be-held-in-beijing-seoul-tokyo-and-la/362006580508849 "'SMTOWN LIVE WORLD TOUR Ⅲ' to be Held in Beijing, Seoul, Tokyo and LA!"]. ''[[Facebook|S.M.Entertainment Official Facebook]]''. 3 April 2012. Retrieved 2012-04-04 *[[Jennifer Lopez]] brought her [[Dance Again World Tour]] to the arena on August 11, 2012. *[[K-pop]] [[boy band]] [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|BIGBANG]] performed their first concert in the U.S. at the arena on November 2 and 3, 2012 as part of their [[Alive Galaxy Tour]]. They returned to the arena on October 4, 2015 for their [[Made World Tour]]. *[[Katy Perry]] brought [[The Prismatic World Tour]] to the arena on September 16 and 17, 2014. *[[Miley Cyrus]] performed in the Center during her [[Bangerz World Tour]] on February 20, 2014 making it Cyrus' 3rd sold-out concert at the Honda Center after previously selling out the Center during her [[Best of Both Worlds Tour]] on November 3, 2007 and again during her [[Wonder World Tour (Miley Cyrus)|Wonder World Tour]] on September 23, 2009. * [[Ariana Grande]] brought [[The Honeymoon Tour]] to the arena on April 10, 2015. She returned to the arena on March 30, 2017 for the [[Dangerous Woman Tour]]. *[[Chris Brown]] performed for a sold-out crowd during his [[One Hell Of a Night Tour]] on September 18, 2015. * [[Selena Gomez]] brought her [[Revival Tour]] to the arena on July 9, 2016. * [[Demi Lovato]] & [[Nick Jonas]] brought their [[Future Now Tour]] to the arena on August 17, 2016. * [[Pentatonix]] brought their [[Pentatonix World Tour 2016]] to the arena on October 20, 2016. * [[Twenty One Pilots]] brought their [[Emotional Roadshow World Tour]] to the arena on February 15, 2017. * [[BTS (band)|BTS]] brought their [[2017 BTS Live Trilogy Episode III: The Wings Tour]] to the arena on April 1 and 2, 2017. * [[Live Nation]] hosted their 2017 Southern California Country Megaticket at the center due to the lease being up at [[Irvine Meadows Amphitheatre (Irvine, California)|Irvine Meadows Amphitheater]] which has been demolished to make way for housing. * [[Kendrick Lamar]] brought [[The Damn. Tour]] to the arena on August 11, 2017. * [[Jay-Z]] brought his [[4:44 Tour]] to the arena on October 27, 2017. * [[Mayday (Taiwanese band)|Mayday]] brought their [[Life Tour]] to the arena on November 11, 2017. * [[Imagine Dragons]] brought their [[Evolve Tour]] to the arena on November 16, 2017. * [[Shakira]] brought her [[El Dorado World Tour]] to the arena on August 31, 2018. * [[Fall Out Boy]] brought their [[Mania Tour]] to the arena on September 29, 2018. ===2028 Summer Olympics=== The arena will host indoor [[volleyball]] during the [[2028 Summer Olympics]]. http://la24-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/assets/pdf/LA2024-canditature-part2_english.pdf ===In Film & TV=== *Honda Center was used as the site of the fictional Junior [[Goodwill Games]] in the film ''[[D2: The Mighty Ducks]]''. *A fictional version of the arena, known as "The Pond", is featured in the ''[[Mighty Ducks (TV series)|Mighty Ducks]]'' animated series. *''[[2162 Votes]]'', the [[The West Wing (tv series)|West Wing]] season 6 finale, features the arena for interior shots of the [[Democratic National Convention]]. ==Capacity== {{Col-begin}}{{col-break}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Hockey |- ! style="background:#fff; border-top:#000 5px solid; border-bottom:#b6985a 5px solid;"|Years ! style="background:#fff; border-top:#000 5px solid; border-bottom:#b6985a 5px solid;"|Capacity |- ! style="background:#000; color:#f57d31;"|1993–1994 |

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Johannesburg Stadium | nickname = | image = South Africa-Johannesburg Stadium001.jpg | location = [[Doornfontein]], [[Johannesburg]] | broke_ground = | opened = 1992 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = Ellis Park Stadium (Pty) Ltd.<ref name="Ellispark-jhb-01">{{cite web|url=http://www.ellispark.co.za/content.aspx?Page=63&Menu=63 |title=JHB Stadium Facilities |accessdate=2008-11-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080802000717/http://www.ellispark.co.za/content.aspx?Page=63&Menu=63 |archivedate=2008-08-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Orlando Pirates]] and [[Golden Lions]] training ground | seating_capacity = 37,500 <ref name="Ellispark-jhb-01"/> }} '''Johannesburg Stadium''' is a [[stadium]], in the [[Doornfontein]] suburb of [[Johannesburg]], [[Gauteng Province]], [[South Africa]]. The stadium has a sweeping roof and can accommodate 37,500 people.
It was originally built as an [[Athletics (track and field)|athletics]] stadium, but also hosted [[association football|football]] and [[rugby union|rugby]] matches.
The eighth [[IAAF World Cup in Athletics]] was held at the stadium in [[1998 IAAF World Cup|1998]]. It served as the main stadium for the [[1999 All-Africa Games]].
It is mostly used as a training ground for the [[Orlando Pirates F.C.|Orlando Pirates]] and the [[Golden Lions Rugby Union|Golden Lions]].
[[Michael Jackson]] performed two shows (sold out) on his [[History World Tour]], on 10 and 12 October 1997.
[[Bon Jovi]] performed at the stadium during their [[These Days Tour]] on December 1, 1995.
[[Gloria Estefan]] performed at the stadium during their [[The Evolution Tour]] on March 22, 1997.
[[Tina Turner]] concluded the African leg of her [[Wildest Dreams Tour]], with two consecutive shows, on April 21–22, 1996.
[[U2]] finished their [[Popmart Tour]] at the stadium on March 21, 1998.
[[Kendrick Lamar]] also performed his South African leg of his international tour here on February 8, 2014.
==See also== * [[Ellis Park Stadium]]

page.title: List of dead heat horse races

revision.text:
[[File:Triple dead-heat.jpg|thumb|250px|The first triple dead heat in harness racing: Patchover, Payne Hall, and Penny Maid at Freehold Raceway (USA).]] This '''list of dead heat horse races''' includes wins between two or more horses, where the winner could not be determined by a [[photo finish]]. Before the 20th century, [[Dead heat (racing)|dead heat]] [[Horse racing|horse races]] could be settled by a second deciding race, unless the owners agreed to divide the prize.
* April 24, 1801{{spaced ndash}}in the King's Plate at [[Newmarket Racecourse|Newmarket]], between Worthy and [[Sorcerer (horse)|Sorcerer]], Worthy won in a deciding heat.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Weatherby|first1=Edward|last2=Weatherby|first2=James|title=The Racing Calendar: containing an account of Plates, Matches and Sweepstakes, run for in Great-Britiain and Ireland, in the year 1801. Volume 29|date=1802|publisher=H. Reynell|location=London|page=13|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433066590914;view=1up;seq=77|chapter=April, 1801. Newmarket. First Spring Meeting. Thursday}}</ref> * May 15, 1828{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Epsom Derby]], between [[Cadland]] and [[The Colonel (horse)|The Colonel]]; Cadland won in a deciding heat.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ward|first1=Andrew|title=Horse-Racing Strangest Races: Extraordinary but true stories from over 150 years of racing|date=2015|publisher=Pavilion Books|isbn=9781910232323|page=<!-- no page numbers in ebook -->|edition=2nd|chapter=A run-off for the Derby}}</ref> * June 21, 1832{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Ascot Gold Cup]], between [[Camarine]] and [[Rowton (horse)|Rowton]]; Camarine won in a deciding heat.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Rowton, recently imported—his pedigree and performances|journal=American Turf Register and Sporting Magazine|date=May 1836|volume=VII|issue=9|pages=406–407|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-qoIAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA406|accessdate=2018-02-25}}</ref> * September 18, 1850{{spaced ndash}}in the [[St. Leger Stakes]], between [[Voltigeur (horse)|Voltigeur]] and Russborough; Voltigeur won in a deciding heat.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tattersall|first1=George|title=The Pictorial Gallery of English Race Horses: Containing Portraits of All the Winners of the Derby, Oaks and St. Leger Stakes, During the Last Twenty Years; and a History of the Principal Operations of the Turf|date=1850|publisher=Henry G. Bohn|location=London|pages=388-384|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RclMAAAAYAAJ|chapter=Voltigeur}}</ref> * April 28, 1868{{spaced ndash}}in the [[2000 Guineas]], between [[Formosa (horse)|Formosa]] and Moslem.<ref name="Breedon"/> * May 28, 1884{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Epsom Derby]], between [[Harvester (horse)|Harvester]] and [[St. Gatien]].<ref>{{cite magazine|magazine=Saturday Review of Politics, Literature, Science and Art|date=31 May 1884|publisher=John W. Parker and Son|volume=57|number=1492|pages=716–717|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9lFJAQAAMAAJ|title=The Derby}}</ref> * June 13, 1900{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Coronation Stakes]], between Sainte Nitouche and [[Winifreda (horse)|Winifreda]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW19000809.2.242?end_date=31-08-1900&phrase=0&query=Winifreda&start_date=01-08-1900&type=ARTICLE|title=Racing in England. Ascot. Wednesday, June 13.|date=9 August 1900|publisher=Otago Witness|pages=42|via=Papers Past}}</ref> * July 3, 1900{{spaced ndash}}in the [[July Stakes]], between [[Doricles]] and Veles.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW19000823.2.175?end_date=31-12-1900&phrase=0&query=Doricles&start_date=01-01-1900&type=ARTICLE|title=Racing in England.|date=23 August 1900|publisher=[[Otago Witness]]|pages=43|via=Papers Past}}</ref> * September 27, 1910{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Dewhurst Plate]] at [[Newmarket Racecourse]], between King William and Phryxus. * July 5, 1926{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Carter Handicap]] at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]], between Macaw and Nedana. * June 10, 1944{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Carter Handicap]] at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]], between Brownie, Bossuet, and Wait A Bit; the first '''triple''' dead heat in a stakes race.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Grayson|first1=Harry|title=Handicapper achieves ambition with Aqueduct triple dead heat|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rBQvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=99sFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1881,2312133|accessdate=2018-02-24|work=Ottawa Citizen|date=14 June 1944}}</ref> * April 1951{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Mildmay of Flete Challenge Cup]] at [[Cheltenham Festival]], between Canford and Slender.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Beech|first1=Gavin|title=Brown Advisory and Merriebelle Stable Plate 2018: statistics, trends, history and closing stages|url=https://www.racinguk.com/news/brown-advisory-and-merriebelle-stable-plate-2018-statistics-trends-history-and-closing-stages|website=Racing UK|accessdate=2018-03-04|date=28 February 2018}}</ref> * March 1953{{spaced ndash}}in the [[St James's Place Foxhunter Chase]] at [[Cheltenham Festival]], between Dunboy II and Merry.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Walker|first1=Alan Yuill|title=The Scots & The Turf: Racing and Breeding – The Scottish Influence|date=2017|publisher=Black & White Publishing Ltd|page=<!-- no page numbers in ebook -->|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XbA_DwAAQBAJ|chapter=Appendix: Bruce Family}}</ref> * October 3, 1953{{spaced ndash}}at [[Freehold Raceway]], between Patchover, Payne Hall, and Penny Maid; the first '''triple''' dead heat in harness racing for a win.<ref>{{cite book |last=Pepe |first=Barbara |date=2003 |title=Freehold: A Hometown History |publisher=[[Arcadia Publishing]] |location=[[Charleston, South Carolina]] |isbn=0-7385-2418-2 |pages=84 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=QD9-ctdh2-gC&pg=PA84&lpg=PA84&dq=%22freehold+raceway%22and+%22triple+dead+heat+%22&source=bl&ots=1uQd2ebTtK&sig=0I2KZsTVMEkcNsSnZnpPWt9Nfmk&hl=en&ei=I_r5S8_nF5CTkAXxkP3LCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22freehold%20raceway%22and%20%22triple%20dead%20heat%20%22&f=false |accessdate=2018-03-26}}</ref> * November 3, 1956{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Saab Quality|Hotham Handicap]] at [[Flemington Racecourse]], [[Melbourne]], between Fighting Force, Ark Royal, and Pandie Sun.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/sport/triple-deadheat-in-the-1956-hotham-handicap/2006/11/03/1162340052531.html |title=Triple dead-heat in the 1956 Hotham Handicap - Sport |publisher=The Age |date= |accessdate=2012-05-01}}</ref> * July 3, 1957{{spaced ndash}}at [[Hollywood Park Racetrack]], between Joe's Pleasure, Challenger Tom, and Leaful; the first triple dead-heat for a win at Hollywood Park.<ref>[http://www.scripophily.net/holparinc.html Scripophily] Retrieved June 16, 2011</ref> * November 27, 1957{{spaced ndash}}at [[Roosevelt Raceway (harness racing)|Roosevelt Raceway]] in New York, between Flaxey Dream, Great Knight and Navy Song.<ref>{{cite web|title=Memorable harness racing moments|url=http://www.harnesslink.com/News/MEMORABLE-HARNESS-RACING-MOMENTS-45728|website=Harness Link|accessdate=2018-03-04|date=28 November 2006}}</ref> * December 27, 1957{{spaced ndash}}at Westport Trotting Club, New Zealand, between Wimpy, Night Owl and Keff; the first trotting '''triple''' dead heat determined by a photo finish.<ref>{{cite web|title=Photo finish of the triple dead heat at Westport Races, 27 December 1957.|url=https://westcoast.recollect.co.nz/nodes/view/13886|website=West Coast New Zealand History|accessdate=2018-02-24}}</ref> * October 14, 1970{{spaced ndash}}at [[Windsor Raceway]], Ontario, between Arnold Gem, Banjo Phil, and Bervaldo.<ref>{{cite web|title=The week in harness racing history|url=http://www.harnesslink.com/News/THE-WEEK-IN-HARNESS-RACING-HISTORY-17795|website=Harness Link|accessdate=2018-03-04|date=11 October 2004}}</ref> * August 12, 1972{{spaced ndash}}in the Adios Stakes at [[The Meadows Racetrack and Casino|The Meadows]], between Jay Time and [[Strike Out]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=u2BVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oj4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4490,3389644&dq=strike+out+adios+stakes&hl=en |title=Rare dead heat in Adios Stakes |publisher=News.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-01}}</ref> * April, 1977{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Aintree Hurdle]], between [[Monksfield]] and [[Night Nurse (horse)|Night Nurse]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Racing: Night Nurse put down at the age of 28|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/racing-night-nurse-put-down-at-the-age-of-28-1183125.html|accessdate=2018-02-24|work=The Independent|date=6 November 1998}}</ref> * July 6, 1980{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud]], between [[Dunette]] and [[Shakapour]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Deniel|first1=Louis|title=La cravache dans le gazon|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/archives/article/1980/07/12/la-cravache-dans-le-gazon_2794735_1819218.html|accessdate=2018-03-04|work=[[Le Monde]]|date=12 July 1980|language=fr}}</ref> * May, 1984{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Lockinge Stakes]], between [[Cormorant Wood]] and [[Wassl]] * January 28, 1987{{spaced ndash}}in the Rod Carmichael Handicap at [[Stony Creek, Victoria|Stony Creek Racecourse]], between Fast Seal, Mr Spectre and Chesterfield; a '''triple''' dead heat.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hillier|first1=Keith|title=Second King Chasing Cup Treble|url=https://www.racingandsports.com.au/en/racing-around/second-king-chasing-cup-treble-story-297724|website=Racing and Sports|accessdate=2018-01-31|date=5 March 2014}}</ref> * May 2, 1988{{spaced ndash}}at Hippodrome Trois Rivieres, between Jack Des Rivieres, Kingwood Tog and H F Elaine; the fifteenth '''triple''' dead heat for a win in harness racing history.<ref>[https://archive.is/20121217161907/https://www.harnesslink.com/www/Article.cgi?ID=2818 This Week in Harness Racing History] Retrieved 2010-5-24</ref> * October 14, 1988{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Dewhurst Stakes]], between [[Prince of Dance]] and [[Scenic (horse)|Scenic]].<ref name="Breedon">{{cite book|last1=Abelson|first1=Edward|last2=Tyrrel|first2=John| title=The Breedon Book of Horse Racing Records|publisher=Breedon Books Publishing |year=1993|isbn=978-1-873626-15-3}}</ref> * August 5, 1989{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Hambletonian Stakes]], between Park Avenue Joe and Probe; a court case determined the proportion of the purse awarded to each horse.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hambletonian ruling upheld|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1990/04/18/Hambletonian-ruling-upheld/5362640411200/?spt=su|accessdate=2018-02-24|work=UPI|date=18 April 1990|language=en}}</ref> * 1995{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Hong Kong Champions & Chater Cup]], between Makarpura Star and Survey King.<ref>{{cite web|title=Results - Racing Information - Horse Racing - The Hong Kong Jockey Club|url=http://www.hkjc.com/english/racing/results.asp?racedate=13/05/1995&raceno=07|website=Hong Kong Jockey Club|accessdate=2018-02-24|date=13 May 1995}}</ref> * December 7, 1995{{spaced ndash}}in Race 4 at [[Hollywood Park Racetrack]], between Tina Celesta, Chans Pearl and Cool Miss Ann; a '''triple''' dead heat.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Christine|first1=Bill|title=Walkover upstaged by triple dead heat|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/dec/08/sports/sp-62030|accessdate=2018-03-04|work=Los Angeles Times|date=8 December 1997}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Finley|first1=Bill|title=One-horse race before 3-way dead heat|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/sports/one-horse-race-3-way-dead-heat-article-1.783673|accessdate=2018-03-04|work=NY Daily News|date=8 December 1997|language=en}}</ref> * May 12, 1996{{spaced ndash}}in the third race at [[Yakima Meadows]], between Fly Like A Angel, Allihavonztheradio and Terri After Five; a '''triple''' dead heat.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Associated Press|title=Rare Triple Dead Heat at Yakima Meadows|url=http://lasvegassun.com/news/1996/may/13/horse-racing-rarity-3-way-dead-heat-at-yakima-trac/|accessdate=17 May 2016|publisher=The Spokesman Review|date=13 May 1996}}</ref> * September 27, 1998{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Kentucky Cup Classic Stakes|Kentucky Cup Classic]], between [[Silver Charm]] and Wild Rush.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Jack|title=Silver Charm, Wild Rush In Dead Heat|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-09-27/sports/9809270273_1_wild-rush-silver-charm-dead-heat|accessdate=2018-01-31|work=Chicago Tribune|date=27 September 1998|language=en}}</ref> * 2003{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Breeders' Cup Turf]] at [[Santa Anita Park]], between [[High Chaparral]] and [[Johar]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Andersen|first1=Steve|title=High Chaparral, Johar inseparable at wire|url=http://www.drf.com/news/high-chaparral-johar-inseparable-wire|accessdate=2018-03-04|work=Daily Racing Form|date=24 October 2003|language=en}}</ref> * March 2004{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Dubai Duty Free Stakes]] at [[Nad Al Sheba Racecourse]], between Right Approach and Paolini.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ford|first1=Jason|title=Dubai Duty Free ends with first dead-heat in World Cup history|url=https://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/176650/dubai-duty-free-ends-with-first-dead-heat-in-world-cup-history|website=BloodHorse.com|date=27 March 2004}}</ref> * September 2004{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Doncaster Cup]], between [[Millenary]] and Kasthari * March 2006{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Doncaster Mile Stakes]], between Kandidate and Vanderlin * September 30, 2007{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Fenwolf Stakes]] at Ascot, between Distinction and Solent * March 2009{{spaced ndash}} at [[The Meadows Racetrack and Casino|The Meadows]], between Tsm Goldenridge, Serious Damage and Teen Elvis; the 25th '''triple''' dead heat in harness racing history.<ref>{{cite web|title=Historic finish highlights Tuesday card in Pittsburgh|url=http://www.harnessracing.com/news/historicfinishhighlightstuesdaycardinpittsburgh.html|website=www.harnessracing.com|accessdate=2018-02-24|date=29 March 2009}}</ref> * May 23, 2010{{spaced ndash}}in the 71st [[Yushun Himba]] ("Japanese Oaks") at [[Tokyo Racecourse]], between [[Apapane (horse)|Apapane]] and Saint Emilion; the first Japanese Grade I race to result in a dead heat for the win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://japanracing.jp/_news2010/100523.html |title=Apapane, Saint Emilion take Yushun Himba in deadheat |publisher=Japanracing.jp |date=2010-05-23 |accessdate=2012-05-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://japanracing.jp/_news2010/pdf/100523.pdf |title=Detailed analysis and results of the 71st Yushun Himba |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-05-01}}</ref> * April 17, 2011{{spaced ndash}}in the Maharaja Harisinghji Trophy at [[Mahalaxmi Racecourse]], [[Mumbai]], between Sprint Star and Misschievous Trot; the first dead heat in a graded race in the history of [[Horse racing in India|Indian horse racing]]. * July 16, 2011{{spaced ndash}}in the [[American Oaks]] at [[Hollywood Park Racetrack|Hollywood Park]], between Cambina and Nereid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drf.com/news/hollywood-park-dead-heat-american-oaks |title=Hollywood Park: Dead heat in American Oaks |publisher=Daily Racing Form |date=2011-07-16 |accessdate=2012-08-25}}</ref> * September 10, 2011{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Irish St. Leger]], between [[Duncan (horse)|Duncan]] and [[Jukebox Jury (horse)|Jukebox Jury]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thoroughbredtimes.com/racing-news/2011/09/10/irish-st-leger-dead-heat.aspx |title=Classic finish for Jukebox Jury, Duncan in Irish St. Leger dead heat (w/ VIDEO) |publisher=Thoroughbred Times |date=2011-09-10 |accessdate=2012-08-25}}</ref> * August 25, 2012{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Travers Stakes]], between [[Alpha (horse)|Alpha]] and Golden Ticket.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equibase.com/premium/eqbSummaryResultsDisplay.cfm?TRK=SAR&CY=USA&DATE=08/25/2012&STYLE=SAR#RN12 |title=New York Racing Association - Saratoga |date=2012-08-25 |accessdate=2012-08-25}}</ref> * August 31, 2013{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Atalanta Stakes]], between [[Integral (horse)|Integral]] and Ladys First.<ref>{{cite web|title=Today's Horse Racing Results|url=http://www.racingpost.com/horses/result_home.sd?race_id=584952|website=Racing Post|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924151227/http://www.racingpost.com/horses/result_home.sd?race_id=584952#results_top_tabs=re_&results_bottom_tabs=ANALYSIS|archivedate=24 September 2015|date=31 August 2013}}</ref> * April 11, 2014{{spaced ndash}}at [[Evangeline Downs]], between All In The Art, Chessie Slew, and Memories Of Trina; a '''triple''' dead heat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/84345/triple-dead-heat-for-win-at-evangeline-downs |title=Triple Dead Heat for Win at Evangeline Downs |date=2014-04-12 |accessdate=2014-04-15}}</ref> * May 31, 2014{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Grand Cup]] at [[York Racecourse|York]], between Clever Cookie and Ralston Road.<ref>{{cite web|title=Full Result 2.20 York|url=https://www.racingpost.com/results/107/york/2014-05-31/602002|website=Racing Post|accessdate=2018-02-10|date=31 May 2014}}</ref> * October 18, 2014{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Caulfield Sprint]] at [[Caulfield Racecourse]], Melbourne, between Miracles of Life and Bel Sprinter.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Habel|first1=Tim|title=Pint-sized Miracles Of Life and enigmatic Bel Sprinter in dead heat for Caulfield Sprint win|url=http://www.theage.com.au/sport/horseracing/pintsized-miracles-of-life-and-enigmatic-bel-sprinter-in-dead-heat-for-caulfield-sprint-win-20141018-1186ea.html|accessdate=2018-01-31|work=The Age|date=18 October 2014}}</ref> * December 19, 2015{{spaced ndash}}in [[the Ladbroke Handicap Hurdle]] at [[Ascot Racecourse|Ascot]], between Jolly's Cracked It and Sternrubin.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sternrubin and Jolly's Cracked It dead-heat in The Ladbroke Hurdle 2015|url=http://www.racingbetter.co.uk/race/ascot/2015/ladbroke_hurdle.html|website=RacingBetter.co.uk|accessdate=2018-03-04}}</ref> * September 3, 2016{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Spinaway Stakes]] at [[Saratoga Race Course|Saratoga Racecourse]], between Sweet Loretta and Pretty City Dancer.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Welsch|first1=Mike|title=Sweet Loretta, Pretty City Dancer hit wire together in Spinaway {{!}} Daily Racing Form|url=http://www.drf.com/news/sweet-loretta-pretty-city-dancer-hit-wire-together-spinaway|accessdate=2018-03-04|work=Daily Racing Form|date=3 September 2016|language=en}}</ref> * November 12, 2016{{spaced ndash}}in the [[High Sheriff of Gloucestershire's Mares' Standard Open NH Flat Race]] at [[Cheltenham Racecourse]], between My Khaleesi and Irish Roe.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Richmond|first1=Tom|title=The Northallerton pig farmers with two horses and dreams of Cheltenham glory|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/horse-racing/the-northallerton-pig-farmers-with-two-horses-and-dreams-of-cheltenham-glory-1-8426542|accessdate=2018-02-01|work=[[The Yorkshire Sports Horse Racing|date=12 November 2016}}</ref> * September 22, 2018{{spaced ndash}}in the [[Ayr Gold Cup]], between Baron Bolt and Son of Rest.<ref>{{cite web |title=William Hill Ayr Gold Cup (Heritage Handicap) |url=https://www.racingpost.com/results/3/ayr/2018-09-22/708225 |website=Racing Post |date=22 September 2018}}</ref>

ALBA Berlin win 133–126 on aggregate. **'''[[Valencia BC|Power Elec Valencia]]''' {{flagicon|ESP}} 85–67 (71–64) {{flagicon|GRC}} [[Aris BC|Aris BSA 2003]]. Valencia win 156–131 on aggregate. **'''[[CB Bilbao Berri|Bizkaia Bilbao Basket]]''' {{flagicon|ESP}} 46–52 (59–47) {{flagicon|CZE}} [[ČEZ Basketball Nymburk|ČEZ Nymburk]]. Bilbao win 105–99 on aggregate. **[[CB Gran Canaria|Gran Canaria 2014]] {{flagicon|ESP}} 75–68 (70–81) {{flagicon|GRC}} '''[[Panellinios Gymnastikos Syllogos BC|Panellinios BC]]'''. Panellinios win 149–145 on aggregate. *[[2010 College Basketball Invitational|College Basketball Invitational]] Final, Game 2 in [[Chaifetz Arena|St. Louis]]: **'''[[Virginia Commonwealth Rams men's basketball|Virginia Commonwealth]]''' 71, [[2009–10 Saint Louis Billikens men's basketball team|Saint Louis]] 65. ====[[American football]]==== * The [[National Football League|NFL]] announces a change to its overtime rule for postseason play, effective [[2010 NFL season|next season]]. Under the new rule, the loser of the coin toss at the start of overtime will have an offensive possession if the winner of the toss scores a field goal on its first possession. ====[[Rugby union]]==== *[[2010 Six Nations Championship#Week 5|Six Nations Championship, week 5]]: **{{ru-rt|WAL}} 33–10 {{ru|ITA}} in [[Millennium Stadium|Cardiff]] **{{ru-rt|IRE}} 20–23 {{ru|SCO}} in [[Croke Park|Dublin]] ***With this result, France win their fifth [[Six Nations Championship]]. **{{ru-rt|FRA}} 12–10 {{ru|ENG}} in [[Stade de France|Paris]] ***France complete their ninth [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]] and the first since 2004. ***Final standings: France 10 points, Ireland 6, England 5, Wales 4, Scotland 3, Italy 2. *[[2011 Rugby World Cup qualifying]]: **[[2008-2010 European Nations Cup First Division|European Nations Cup First Division]], matchday 10: ***{{ru-rt|Portugal}} 9–20 {{ru|Romania}} in [[Estádio Universitário de Lisboa|Lisbon]] ****Romania secure third place in the competition and advance to the [[2011 Rugby World Cup – Europe qualification#Round 2: European Nations Cup Champions Playoff Series|European qualification playoffs]] for a spot in the [[2011 Rugby World Cup Final Place Play-off|final place playoff]]. ***{{ru-rt|Georgia}} 36–8 {{ru|Russia}} in [[Akçaabat Fatih Stadium|Trabzon]], [[Turkey]] ****In a contest between teams already qualified for the World Cup, Georgia's win gives them the ENC title for the second straight time and third overall. ***{{ru-rt|Germany}} 17–21 {{ru|Spain}} in [[Fritz-Grunebaum-Sportpark|Heidelberg]] ****Germany are relegated to [[European Nations Cup (rugby union)|European Nations Cup]] Division 2A. ****Standings (10 games unless stated otherwise): Georgia 27 points, Russia 25, Portugal 21, Romania 20 (9), Spain 13 (9), Germany 10.

====[[Cricket]]==== *[[English cricket team in Bangladesh in 2009–10|England in Bangladesh]]: **[[English cricket team in Bangladesh in 2009–10#2nd ODI|2nd ODI]] in [[Sher-e-Bangla Cricket Stadium|Mirpur]]: ***{{cr|BAN}} 260/6 (50.0 overs); {{cr|ENG}} 261/8 (48.5 overs, [[Eoin Morgan|EJG Morgan]] 110[[Not out|*]]). '''England win by 2 wickets, lead the 3–match series 2–0.'''
====[[Field hockey]]==== *[[2010 Men's Hockey World Cup|Men's World Cup]] in [[Dhyan Chand National Stadium|New Delhi, India]]: **[[2010 Men's Hockey World Cup#Pool B|Pool B]]: ***{{fh-rt|South Africa}} 4–6 {{fh|England}} ***{{fh-rt|Pakistan}} 2–1 {{fh|Spain}} ***{{fh-rt|India}} 2–5 {{fh|Australia}} ****Standings (after 2 matches): England 6 points, Australia, Spain, India, Pakistan 3, South Africa 0.
====[[Association football|Football (soccer)]]==== *[[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification|European Under-21 Championship qualification]]: (teams in <s>strike</s> are eliminated) **[[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification Group 3|Group 3]]: <s>{{fbu-rt|21|LUX}}</s> 0–1 {{fbu|21|BIH}} ***Standings: {{fbu|21|WAL}} 13 points (6 matches), {{fbu|21|HUN}} 9 (4), {{fbu|21|ITA}}, Bosnia and Herzegovina 7 (5), Luxembourg 4 (8), **[[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification Group 4|Group 4]]: {{fbu-rt|21|ESP}} 3–1 <s>{{fbu|21|LIE}}</s> ***Standings: {{fbu|21|NLD}} 15 points (5 matches), Spain 12 (5), {{fbu|21|POL}} 9 (5), {{fbu|21|FIN}} 3 (5), Liechtenstein 0 (6). **[[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification Group 5|Group 5]]: ***{{fbu-rt|21|GER}} 2–2 {{fbu|21|ISL}} ***<s>{{fbu-rt|21|SMR}}</s> 0–3 <s>{{fbu|21|NIR}}</s> ****Standings: {{fbu|21|CZE}} 15 points (5 matches), Iceland 13 (6), Germany 8 (5), Northern Ireland 4 (6), San Marino 0 (6) **[[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification Group 10|Group 10]]: {{fbu-rt|21|SCO}} 2–2 <s>{{fbu|21|AZE}}</s> ***Standings: Scotland, {{fbu|21|AUT}} 13 points (6 matches), {{fbu|21|BLR}} 12 (5), <s>{{fbu|21|ALB}}</s> 4 (7), Azerbaijan 1 (6) *Friendly international match: **{{fb-rt|IRL}} 0–2 {{fb|BRA}} in [[Emirates Stadium|London, England]]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2017}} {{infobox stadium |stadium_name=Memorial Stadium |location=[[Asheville, North Carolina]] |broke_ground= 1924 |opened= 1925 |owner=City of Asheville |operator= City of Asheville |surface=Artificial turf |tenants= '''Current'''
Asheville Grizzlies (CCFL)
[[Asheville City SC]] ([[National Premier Soccer League|NPSL]]) (2017–)
'''Past'''
[[Asheville Splash]] ([[USL W-League|W-Lg]]) (2001–2004)
Asheville Bears
Asheville Assault ([[National Women's Football Association|NWFA]]) |seating_capacity=5,000 }} '''Memorial Stadium''' is a [[multi-use stadium]] located in [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. The stadium was completed in 1925 to serve as a regional athletic and special events facility. Memorial Stadium is not to be confused with the similarly named [[Asheville High School]] Memorial Stadium. Memorial Stadium's entrance was originally intended to serve as a memorial to [[Western North Carolina]]'s war veterans but the memorial was never entirely completed. Recently plans have been set afoot to complete the memorial. As part of a large scale renovation of the facility which included the installation of a new [[artificial turf]] playing surface, there are plans to move a [[World War II]] memorial onto the site. Memorial Stadium is currently home to the Asheville Grizzlies - a semi-pro [[American football|football]] team in the Central Carolina Football League - and Asheville City Soccer Club, who compete in the [[National Premier Soccer League]]. Memorial Stadium sits adjacent to [[McCormick Field]], home of the [[South Atlantic League]]'s [[Asheville Tourists]]. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131004215953/http://www.ashevillenc.gov/Departments/ParksRecreation/ParksOverview/ParksFacilitiesInventory.aspx Asheville Parks and Recreation: Parks & Facilities Inventory] {{coord|35.586619|-82.547879|display=t}} {{WNC sports venues}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Asheville, North Carolina]] [[Category:High school football venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:Sports in Asheville, North Carolina]] [[Category:1925 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1925]] [[Category:American football venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:National Premier Soccer League stadiums]]

revision.comment: /* Construction */Scam warning on Lunocet from personal experience.
revision.text:
{{short description| Single blade swimfin attached to both feet }} {{Refimprove|date=May 2013}} [[File:Junko-Kitahama Apnea-Monofin cropped.jpg|thumb|A freediver using a monofin]] [[File:Herbert Nitsch at the Cyprus BIOS 2004 Freediving Open Classic.JPG|thumb|[[Herbert Nitsch]] wearing a monofin at the Cyprus BIOS 2004 Freediving Open Classic]]
A '''monofin''' is a type of [[swimfin]] typically used in [[underwater sports]] such as [[finswimming]], [[free-diving]] and [[underwater orienteering]]. It consists of a single or linked [[control surface (fluid dynamics)|surface]]s attached to both of the diver's feet. The diver's appearance is then reminiscent of a [[mermaid]] or [[merman]].
The arrival of the monofin in the early 1970s led to the breaking of all finswimming world records by the end of the decade due to the improved performance possible when used instead of two ordinary swimfins.<ref name=luigiferraro>{{cite web|title=Finswimming|url=http://www.luigiferraro.it/en/finswimming|publisher=Official site dedicated to Luigi Ferraro|accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
== Use == To differentiate between the use of monofins and conventional fins, the latter are sometimes referred to as '''stereo fins''' or '''bi-fins'''.
The monofin swimmer extends arms forward, locking hands together, locking the head between the biceps. The undulating movement starts in the shoulders, with maximum amplitude towards the hips, the legs almost don't bend to transfer the movement to the monofin. This technique is called the '''dolphin kick'''.
By slowly oscillating the surface of the monofin when submerged, divers can generate large amounts of [[thrust]] even with small or slow movements. This preserves [[energy]] which helps when breathholding ([[apnea]]).
==History and production== Monofins were introduced in 1972 by a [[USSR|Soviet]]{{cn|date=July 2015}} finswimming club and have been used for finswimming competitions since, allowing monofin swimmers to reach speeds of 12 km/h.<ref>{{cite web|title= Dolphin-Inspired Man-Made Fin Works Swimmingly|url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/dolphin-inspired-man-made-fin/|publisher= Scientific American|accessdate= 17 Sep 2016}}</ref> Traditional [[List_of_world_records_in_finswimming#Men|monofin 50 m apnea world record]] is as fast as 13 km/h.
===Construction=== [[File:Skorjenkoflosse.jpg|thumb|Monofin]] Monofins can be made of [[glass fiber]], [[carbon fiber]] or [[aluminum]] and [[rubber]]. The diver's [[muscle]] power, swimming style, and the type of aquatic activity the monofin is used for determining the choice of size, stiffness, and materials.
Most monofins consist of a single, wide, glass or carbon fiber reinforced composite blade with graded flexibility attached to the diver by two rubber foot pockets. The leading edge may be thickened and faired. The blade flexibility is generally controlled by tapering the amount of fibre and thickness of the blade to make the trailing edge thinner and more flexible.
The [[Lunocet]] is a later type of monofin which uses bio-mimicry of dolphin flukes in an attempt to improve efficiency. It uses cycling shoes to connect to the diver for comfortable wear and power transfer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimateswimfin.com/|title=Buy the Best Monofin - Lunocet - comfortable freediving, apnea & apnee |work=ultimateswimfin.com}}</ref>
Please do not promote Lunocet without a scam warning. He took $400 from me, but never delivered even though he called me after a year waiting with an upgrade offer. I then checked the website for trading standards in his State and saw that he had scammed many other people too. His publicity is good and high profile users evidently get deliveries. Ordinary mortals will just lose their money.
==See also== * [[Mermaiding]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{commonscat}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8QEZPTFFdLU Good monofin technique with the Lunocet] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pAA9Md1C7s Rick Waldock: Monofin - freediving in Bonaire] *[https://archive.is/20130615221531/http://www.finswimmer.com/tools/monofin-manufacturers/?fromEvidence=true Monofin Manufacturers]

The film stars [[Josh Helman]], [[Chanel Cresswell]], [[Michael Bisping]] and [[John Hurt]] in his penultimate film role. == Cast == * [[Josh Helman]] as [[Lenny McLean]] * [[Chanel Cresswell]] as Valerie McLean * [[Michael Bisping]] as [[Roy Shaw]] * [[John Hurt]] as Leslie Salmon * [[Nick Moran]] as Johnny Bootnose * [[Charley Palmer Rothwell]] - Carrots McLean * [[Rita Tushingham]] as Reenie Joyce * [[Cathal Pendred]] as Roofie == Production == [[Principal photography]] on the film began on 22 August 2016 in the [[London]] neighbourhoods of [[Hoxton]] and [[Islington]].{{cite news|last1=Barraclough|first1=Leo|title=Boxing Movie ‘My Name Is Lenny’ Starts to Shoot in London (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/global/boxing-movie-my-name-is-lenny-london-1201841922/|accessdate=September 17, 2016|work=Variety|date=August 22, 2016}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|2024521}} [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British sports films]] [[Category:British drama films]] [[Category:2010s sports films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Drama films based on actual events]] [[Category:Sports films based on actual events]] [[Category:Sports drama films]] [[Category:Films shot in London]] [[Category:British biographical films]] [[Category:2010s biographical films]] {{sport-film-stub}}
