[[Canadian football|Football]]: 66,308[http://cfl.ca/greycupcentral/year/2008 Stamps spoil party in Montreal with big 'W' at 'Big O'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015142252/http://cfl.ca/greycupcentral/year/2008 |date=October 15, 2012 }}. cfl.ca. Retrieved April 28, 2015
Concert: 78,322 | dimensions = '''Foul Lines''' – {{convert|325|ft|m|0}} (1977), {{convert|330|ft|m|0}} (1981), {{convert|325|ft|m|0}} (1983)
'''Power Alleys''' – {{convert|375|ft|m|0}}
'''Centre Field''' – {{convert|404|ft|m|0}} (1977), {{convert|405|ft|m|0}} (1979), {{convert|404|ft|m|0}} (1980), {{convert|400|ft|m|0}} (1981), {{convert|404|ft|m|0}} (1983)
'''Backstop''' – {{convert|62|ft|m|0}} (1977), {{convert|65|ft|m|0}} (1983), {{convert|53|ft|m|0}} (1989) | website = {{URL|parcolympique.qc.ca/en/the-park/olympic-stadium/|Parc Olympique Quebec}} }} '''Olympic Stadium'''{{cite web|url=https://parcolympique.qc.ca/en/what-to-do/olympic-stadium/|title=The Stadium|website=Part olympique|accessdate=May 12, 2018}} ({{lang-fr|Stade olympique}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in Canada, located at [[Olympic Park, Montreal|Olympic Park]] in the [[Hochelaga-Maisonneuve]] district of [[Montreal]]. Built in the mid-1970s as the [[Olympic Stadium|main venue]] for the [[1976 Summer Olympics]], it is nicknamed "The Big O", a reference to both its name and to the [[doughnut]]-shape of the permanent component of the stadium's roof. It is also called "The Big Owe" to reference the astronomical cost of the stadium and the 1976 Olympics as a whole. The stadium is the largest by seating capacity in Canada. After the Olympics, [[artificial turf]] was installed and it became the home of Montreal's professional [[Major League Baseball|baseball]] and [[Canadian Football League|football]] teams. The [[Montreal Alouettes]] of the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]] returned to their previous home of [[Percival Molson Memorial Stadium|Molson Stadium]] in [[1998 Montreal Alouettes season|1998]] for regular season games, but continued to use Olympic Stadium for playoff and [[Grey Cup]] games until 2014 when they returned to [[Percival Molson Memorial Stadium|Molson Stadium]] for all of their games. Following the [[2004 Montreal Expos season|2004]] baseball season, the [[Montreal Expos|Expos]] relocated to Washington, D.C. to become the [[Washington Nationals]]. The stadium currently serves as a [[multipurpose stadium|multipurpose facility]] for special events (e.g. concerts, trade shows) with a permanent [[seating capacity]] of 56,040.[http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/can/olympic_stadium_montreal Olympic Stadium]. stadiumdb.com. Retrieved April 28, 2015 The capacity is expandable with temporary seating. The [[Montreal Impact]] of [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) use the venue on occasion, when demand for tickets justifies the large capacity or when the weather restricts outdoor play at nearby [[Saputo Stadium]] in the spring months. The stadium has not had a main tenant since the Expos left in 2004. Despite decades of use, the stadium's history of numerous structural and financial problems has largely branded it a [[white elephant]]. Incorporated into the north base of the stadium is the Montreal Tower, the world's tallest [[inclined tower]] at {{convert|175|m}}. The stadium and [[Olympic Park, Montreal|Olympic Park]] grounds border [[Maisonneuve Park]], which includes the [[Montreal Botanical Garden]], adjacent to the west across [[Sherbrooke Street|Rue Sherbrooke]] ([[Quebec Route 138|Route 138]]). ==History== ===Background and architecture=== As early as 1963, [[Mayor of Montreal|Montreal Mayor]] [[Jean Drapeau]] sought to build a covered stadium in Montreal.Costello, Rory. [http://sabr.org/bioproj/park/477659 Olympic Stadium (Montreal)]. [[Society for American Baseball Research]], 2013. A covered stadium was thought to be all but essential for Drapeau's other goal of bringing a Major League Baseball team to Montreal, given the cold weather that can affect the city in April, October and sometimes even September. In 1967, soon after the [[National League]] granted Montreal an expansion franchise for 1969, Drapeau wrote a letter promising that any prospective Montreal team would be playing in a covered stadium by 1971. However, even as powerful as he was, he did not have the power to make such a guarantee on his own authority. Just as [[Charles Bronfman]], who was slated to become the franchise's first owner, was ready to walk away, Drapeau had his staffers draw up a proposal for a stadium. It was enough to persuade Bronfman to continue with the effort. [[File:Montreal Olympic Stadium tower with cables for retractable roof.jpg|thumb|left|Tower with cables for retractable roof]] The stadium was designed by French architect [[Roger Taillibert]] to be an elaborate facility featuring a [[retractable roof]],{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JhUyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yaQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5430%2C4071162 |newspaper=Montreal Gazette |title=Big O architect to do roof study |date=June 10, 1981 |page=1}} which was to be opened and closed by cables suspended from a huge {{convert|175|m|ft|sigfig=3|adj=on}} tower – the tallest inclined structure in the world, and the [[List of tallest buildings in Montreal|sixth tallest]] structure in Montreal. The design of the stadium resembles that of the Australian Pavilion at [[Expo '70]] in [[Osaka, Japan]].{{cite web|author=Chris Glenn |url=http://en.japantourist.jp/view/yokkaichi-s-platypus-pavilion |title=Yokkaichi's Platypus Pavilion | Mie | Japan Tourist, by Chris Glenn |publisher=En.japantourist.jp |date=November 30, 2011 |accessdate=September 26, 2013}} Soon after Montreal was awarded the 1976 Games, Drapeau struck a secret deal with Taillibert to build the stadium. It only came to light in 1972. The [[Olympic Pool (Montreal)|Olympic swimming pool]] is located under this tower. An Olympic [[velodrome]] (since converted to the [[Montreal Biodome]], an indoor nature museum) was situated at the base of the tower in a building similar in design to the swimming pool. The building was built as the [[Olympic Stadium|main stadium]] for the 1976 Summer Olympic Games. The stadium was host to various events including the [[Olympic Games#Ceremonies|opening and closing ceremonies]], [[Athletics at the 1976 Summer Olympics|athletics]], [[Football at the 1976 Summer Olympics|football]] finals, and the team jumping [[Equestrian at the 1976 Summer Olympics|equestrian]] events.[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1976/1976v2.pdf 1976 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 2. pp. 42–65. The building's design is cited as a masterpiece of Organic Modern architecture.Rémillard, 196. Taillibert based the building on plant and animal forms, aiming to include vertebral structures with sinews or tentacles, while still following the basic plans of [[Modern architecture]]. ===Construction=== [[Image:Le Stade Olympique de Montréal Nuit Arriere Edit 1.jpg|thumb|left|Back view at night]] The stadium was originally slated to be finished in 1972, but the grand opening was cancelled due to a strike by construction workers. The ''Conseil des métiers de la construction'' union headed by [[André Desjardins|André "Dédé" Desjardins]] kept the construction site in "anarchic disorder" until the Quebec Premier [[Robert Bourassa]] bought him off in a secret deal.{{cite web | last = Bauch | first = Hubert | coauthors = | title = Taillibert: blame Ottawa, Quebec | work = | publisher = ''The Montreal Gazette'' |date=September 14, 2000 | url = http://www.telusplanet.net/public/mozuz/crime/lemieszewski20001102.html | doi = | accessdate = December 7, 2017}} In his 2000 book ''Notre Cher Stade Olympique'', Taillibert wrote "If the Olympic Games took place, it was thanks to Dédé Desjardins. What irony!" Further delays ensued due to the stadium's unusual design and Taillibert's unwillingess to back down from his original vision of the stadium even in the face of escalating costs for raw materials. It did not help that the original project manager, Trudeau et Associés, seemed to be incapable of handling some of the most basic construction tasks. The Quebec provincial government finally lost patience with the delays and cost overruns in 1974, and threw Taillibert off the project. Additionally, the project was plagued by circumstances beyond anyone's control. Work slowed to a snail's pace for a third of the year due to Montreal's typically brutal winters. As a result, the stadium and tower remained unfinished at the opening of the 1976 Olympic Games.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/montreals-billion-dollar-big-owe-what-went-wrong-in-76/article1152036/|title=Montreal's billion-dollar 'Big Owe': What went wrong in '76?|last=Peritz|first=Ingrid|date=January 17, 2009|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=January 19, 2009|location=Toronto}} The roof materials languished in a warehouse in [[Marseille]] until 1982, and the tower and roof were not completed until 1987.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/buildingbig/wonder/structure/olympic_stadium.html|title=Building big: Databank: Olympic Stadium|publisher=WGBH|accessdate=July 16, 2009}} It would be another year before the 66-tonne, {{convert|5500|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} [[Kevlar]] roof could retract. Even then, it could not be used in winds above {{convert|40|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}. Ultimately, it was only opened and closed 88 times. ===Observatory=== [[image:Montreal Olympic stadium funicular view..jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.5|North-east view from elevator lower deck compartment]] When construction on the stadium's tower resumed after the 1976 Olympics, a multi-storey observatory was added to the plan, accessible via a [[inclined elevator]], opened in 1987, that travels {{convert|266|m|}} along the curved tower's spine. The elevator cabin ascends from base of the tower to upper deck in less than two minutes at a rate of {{convert|2.8|m/s|mph|abbr=on}}, with space for 76 persons per trip and a capacity of 500 persons per hour. The cabin is designed to remain level throughout its trip, while providing a panoramic view to its passengers. The elevator faces north-east, offering a view to the north, south and east. It overlooks the Olympic Village, the Biodome, the Botanical Gardens and Saputo Stadium. The Olympic Park, the stadium's suspended roof and downtown Montreal can be viewed from the south-west facing Observatory at the top of the tower. ===Stadium financing=== [[Image:Aerial view of Olympic Stadium (Montreal) as seen at night.jpg|thumb|right|Aerial view at night]] Despite initial projections in 1970 that the stadium would cost only [[Canadian dollar|C$]]134 million to construct, strikes and construction delays served to escalate these costs. By the time the stadium opened (in an unfinished form), the total costs had risen to C$1.1 billion. The Quebec government introduced a special tobacco tax in May 1976 to help recoup its investment. By 2006, the amount contributed to the stadium's owner, the Olympic Installations Board (OIB) ([[French language|fr]]: Régie des Installations Olympiques), accounted for 8% of the tax revenue earned from cigarette sales. The 1976 special tobacco tax act stipulated that once the stadium was paid off, ownership of the facility would be returned to the City of Montreal. In mid-November 2006, the stadium's costs were finally paid in full, more than 30 years after it opened.{{cite news|author=CBC News |title=Quebec's Big Owe stadium debt is over |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |date=December 19, 2006 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2006/12/19/qc-olympicstadium.html |accessdate=June 25, 2008 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103103426/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2006/12/19/qc-olympicstadium.html |archivedate=January 3, 2007 }} The total expenditure (including repairs, renovations, construction, [[interest]], and inflation) amounted to C$1.61 billion, making it—at the time all costs were paid off—the second most expensive stadium ever built (after [[Wembley Stadium]] in London).{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/08/06/expensive-stadiums-worldwide-forbeslife-cx_ae_0806sports_slide_10.html?partner=sinatw | work=Forbes |title=In Depth: World's Most Expensive Stadiums | first=Andrew | last=Egan}} Despite initial plans to complete payment in October 2006, an indoor smoking ban introduced in May 2006 curtailed the revenue gathered by the tobacco tax. By 2014, the stadium's expense ranking had fallen to fifth, with the construction of costlier venues like [[MetLife Stadium]], [[AT&T Stadium]], and [[Yankee Stadium|the new Yankee Stadium]]. Perceived by many to be a white elephant, the stadium has also been dubbed ''The Big Owe'' due to its astronomical cost. The stadium has generated on average $20 million in revenue each year since 1977. It is estimated that a large-scale event such as the Grey Cup can generate as much as $50 million in revenue.{{cite web|url=http://rio.intercollab.com/servlet/file?id=66|title=Rio.intercollab.com|publisher=|accessdate=November 23, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713044910/http://rio.intercollab.com/servlet/file?id=66|archivedate=July 13, 2011|df=mdy-all}} ===Continuing problems=== Although the tower and retractable roof were not completed in time for the 1976 Olympics, construction on the tower resumed in the 1980s. During this period, however, a large fire set the tower ablaze, causing damage and forcing a scheduled [[Montreal Expos|Expos]] home game to be postponed. In 1986, a large chunk of the tower fell onto the playing field prior to another Expos game August 29 vs. San Diego Padres forcing a doubleheader on August 30.{{cite web|url=http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1986/B08301MON1986.htm|title=Retrosheet Boxscore: Montreal Expos 10, San Diego Padres 1 (1)|publisher=|accessdate=May 16, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/s/2003/0422/1542317.html |title=ESPN.com: MLB – Merron: What a disaster! |publisher=Static.espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=March 2, 2011}} In January 1985, approval was given by the Quebec government to complete the project and install a retractable roof, financed by an Olympic cigarette tax in the province.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IkolAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qqUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1389%2C1079304 |newspaper=Montreal Gazette |last=Drolet |first=Daniel |title=At last: Big O to get a retractable roof |date=January 24, 1985 |page=A-1 }} The tower construction and installation of the orange-coloured [[Kevlar]] roof were completed by April 1987,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pEMyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=buYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5580%2C3665483 |newspaper=Lawrence (KS) Journal World |agency=Associated Press |title=Olympic Stadium roof in place after 11 years |date=April 15, 1987 |page=5B}} a decade later than planned. The roof experienced numerous rips, allowing rain to leak into the stadium.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mdIwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b24DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2380%2C7801563 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |title=Storm rips Olympic Stadium roof |agency=Associated Press |date=June 28, 1991 |page=20}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mtIwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b24DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3123%2C8136621 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |last=Meyer |first=Paul |title=Olympic Stadium roof damaged and retracted |date=June 29, 1991 |page=18}} As part of various renovations made in 1991 to improve the stadium's suitability as a baseball venue, 12,000 seats were eliminated, most of them in distant portions of the outfield, and home plate was moved closer to the stands. [[File:Batting practice at Olympic Stadium in 2015.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Olympic Stadium's blue roof and new scoreboard installed in 2015]] On September 8 of that year, support beams snapped and caused a {{convert|55|LT|ST t|adj=on|lk=on}} concrete slab to fall onto an exterior walkway. No one was injured, but the Expos had to move their final 13 home games of that season to the opponents' cities. The Expos hinted that the 1992 season was at risk unless the stadium was certified safe. In early November, engineers found the stadium was structurally sound. However, it took longer to certify the roof as safe because it had been badly ripped in a June windstorm. For the 1992 season, it was decided to keep the roof closed at all times. The Kevlar roof was removed in May 1998, making the stadium open-air for the 1998 season. Later in 1998, a $26 million non-retractable opaque blue roof was installed. In 1999, a {{convert|350|m2|sqft|-1|abbr=on}} portion of the roof collapsed on January 18, dumping ice and snow on workers that were setting up for the annual [[Montreal Auto Show]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=11FWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9-sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6874%2C4979213 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |agency=wire services |title=Snow causes roof to cave in at Olympic Stadium |date=January 19, 1999 |page=5D }} The auto show and a boat show the following month were canceled,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8SlUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_I0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2649%2C1387875 |newspaper=Boca Raton News |agency=Associated Press |title=Olympic Stadium out for month |date=January 20, 1999 |page=4B}} and the auto show left the venue for good (since then, the Montreal Auto Show has usually been held at the [[Palais des congrès de Montréal]]). Repaired once again, the roof was modified to better withstand winter conditions: the OIB installed a network of pipes to circulate heated water under the roof to allow for snow melting. Despite these corrective measures, the stadium floor remained closed from December to March.{{Cite news|author=Canwest News Service |title=Impact begin search for location for winter game |newspaper=Montreal Gazette |date=October 2, 2008 |url=https://nationalpost.com/sports/story.html?id=856303 }}{{dead link|date=August 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Birdair, the fabric provider and designer of the roof, was later sued for the roof failure.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/1999/08/30/bigo990830.html |title=Olympic stadium suing U.S. roofers |date=November 10, 2000 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=July 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511124704/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/1999/08/30/bigo990830.html |archivedate=May 11, 2008 }} The installer of the roof, Danny's Construction, having suffered tremendous cost overruns along with its subcontractor Montacier, due to changes in the plans and specifications and delays, was terminated during the construction, and Birdair completed the project. Danny's Construction sued Birdair in 1999.{{cite news|url=http://www.nce.co.uk/dome-supplier-faces-montreal-compensation-battle/831802.article|title=Dome supplier faces Montreal compensation battle|last=Parker|first=Dave|date=January 28, 1999|publisher=New Civil Engineer|accessdate=July 16, 2009}} In February 2010, after a lengthy trial, the Quebec Superior Court awarded a judgement in favour of Danny's Construction and dismissed Birdair's countersuit.La Presse, Actualites, Samedi 13 Fevrier 2010, p. A9 The stadium's condition suffered considerably in the early 21st century. During the Expos' final years in Montreal, it was coated with grime, and much of the concrete was chipped, stained, and soiled. ===Plans for a third roof=== In 2009, the stadium received approval to remain open in the winter, provided weather conditions are favourable.{{cite web|url=https://montrealgazette.com/there+snow/1156453/story.html|title=It's a go for the Big O (if there's no snow)|last=Riga|first=Andrew|date=January 9, 2009|work=Montreal Gazette|publisher=Canwest|accessdate=January 9, 2009}}{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} However, the Olympic Installations Board issued a report stating that the roof was unsafe during heavy rainfall or more than {{convert|8|cm}} of snow, and that it rips 50 to 60 times a year. The city fire department warned in August 2009 that without corrective measures, including a new roof, it may order the stadium closed. Events cannot be held if more than {{convert|3|cm}} of snow are predicted 24 hours in advance, such as caused postponement of the Montreal Impact home opener soccer match in March 2014.{{Citation needed|date=March 2014|reason=both the volume and specific case should be referenced since it's 8cm of snow above.}} A contract for a new permanent steel roof was awarded in 2004, with an estimated $300 million price tag. In June 2010, the Olympic Installations Board sought approval from the provincial government for the contract.{{Cite news | author = CBC News | title = Olympic Stadium to get $300M roof | publisher = Canadian Broadcasting Corporation | date = June 29, 2010 | url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2010/06/29/olympic-stadium-roof.html | accessdate =June 29, 2010 }} In May 2011 a committee was formed to study the future of the stadium and improve the usage of the stadium, pool, and sports centre.{{Cite news |author = Montreal Gazette |title = Committee formed to study future of Montreal's Olympic Stadium |publisher = Postmedia Network Inc. |date = May 8, 2011 |url = https://montrealgazette.com/news/Committee+formed+study+future+Montreal+Olympic+Stadium/4747548/story.html }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite news |author = Montreal Gazette |title = Elephant in the room; Regie's committee on Big O a good start but leaves questions unanswered |publisher = Postmedia Network Inc. |date = May 10, 2011 |url = https://montrealgazette.com/opinion/editorials/Elephant+room/4754746/story.html |access-date = May 28, 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110521195626/http://www.montrealgazette.com/opinion/editorials/Elephant+room/4754746/story.html |archive-date = May 21, 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }} A slab of concrete measuring approximately {{convert|8|by|12|m}} fell from the roof of the stadium's underground parking facility on March 4, 2012. There were no injuries.{{cite news |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20120305/concrete-slab-falls-at-olympic-stadium-120305/ |title=Giant concrete slab falls at Montreal's Olympic Stadium |agency=[[The Canadian Press]] |publisher=[[CTV News]] |date=March 5, 2012 |accessdate=March 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305190037/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20120305/concrete-slab-falls-at-olympic-stadium-120305/ |archivedate=March 5, 2012 |df=mdy }} The roof continues to deteriorate, with 7,453 tears as of May 2017,{{cite news | last = Gentile | first = Davide | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/olympic-stadium-roof-1.4100485 | title = Olympic Stadium roof deteriorating at rapid rate | publisher = CBC | date = May 4, 2017 | accessdate = November 19, 2017 }} limiting use of the venue in winter to when there is three or less centimetres of snow on the roof.{{cite news | last = Lowrie | first = Margan | title = Forty years on, Montreal's Olympic Stadium remembered as more than just a money pit | publisher = National Post | date = July 12, 2016 | accessdate = August 13, 2016}} In 2015, a new high definition scoreboard was installed, replacing the aging two-panel display dating back to the stadium's renovations in 1992.{{cite web|url=http://www.solotech.com/en/casestudy/montreals-olympic-stadium/|title=Montreal's Olympic Stadium – Solotech|work=MKTSOL|accessdate=May 16, 2016}} In November 2017 the Quebec government approved a new roof, estimated to cost $250 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/quebec-olympic-stadium-new-roof-approved-2017-1.4395663|title=Quebec OKs new roof for Big O|publisher=CBC News|date=November 9, 2017|accessdate=November 10, 2017}} The Olympic Installations Board has estimated the cost of demolishing the stadium would be between $500 and $700 million,{{cite news | last = Shingler | first = Benjamin | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/big-o-montreal-olympic-stadium-roof-1.4396721 | title = Dismantling Montreal's Olympic Stadium would be 'foolish,' says man in charge | publisher = CBC | date = November 10, 2017 | accessdate = November 19, 2017 }} though this figure is based on a preliminary two-month study and thus has a high margin of error.{{cite news | last = Lampert | first = Allison | title = WHAT TO DO WITH THE BIG O? | newspaper = Montreal Gazette | language = English | publisher = Montreal Gazette | date = December 7, 2013 | url = https://www.pressreader.com/canada/montreal-gazette/20131207/281479274218140 | access-date = November 19, 2017 }} The new roof would be removable, allowing the stadium to either be open-air or enclosed, consistent with the intent of the original roof. ==Post-Olympic use== === Gridiron football=== [[Image:AlouettesStadeOlympique.jpg|thumb|right|The Alouettes in action in 2010]] The [[Canadian Football League]]'s [[Montreal Alouettes]] became the stadium's first major post-Olympic tenant when they moved their home games there halfway through the [[1976 CFL season|1976 season]]. Capacity was reduced from its Olympic capacity of 72,000 to 58,500, but leapt to 66,308 when the natural grass was replaced with [[AstroTurf]] ahead of the [[1977 CFL season|1977 season]]. The Alouettes remained there through [[1986 CFL season|1986]], the franchise's final season of operations; the team would shut down shortly after the start of the [[1987 CFL season|1987 season]]. A revived Alouettes franchise returned for the [[1996 CFL season|1996]] and [[1997 CFL season|1997 season]]s, but then moved to the [[Percival Molson Memorial Stadium|Percival Molson Stadium]] in 1998, only using the larger Olympic Stadium for select regular-season and home playoff games. As of 2008, the franchise uses Olympic Stadium for playoff games only. Due to the increased popularity of the Alouettes and the small capacity of Percival Molson Stadium, the team considered returning to Olympic Stadium on a full-time basis, but instead renovated Percival Molson Stadium to increase its capacity.{{cite news | author = CBC News | title = Molson Stadium to begin $29.4M expansion | publisher = Canadian Broadcasting Corporation | date = March 9, 2009 | url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2009/03/09/mtl-stadium-expansion.html | accessdate =March 9, 2009 }} In addition, the stadium holds the record for the largest Grey Cup attendance, that of the [[65th Grey Cup|1977 Grey Cup]] game, in which the hometown Montreal Alouettes defeated the Edmonton Eskimos, 41-6 before 68,318 spectators; this despite a local transit strike and harsh winter weather conditions.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/fanfuel/grey-cup-moments/|title=Fan Fuel: Top 10 Grey Cup moments - Sportsnet.ca|publisher=|accessdate=November 23, 2017}} Olympic Stadium has hosted the [[Grey Cup]] a total of six times, most recently in 2008 when the [[Calgary Stampeders]] defeated the hometown Alouettes. The stadium holds the record for nine of the ten [[CFL attendance|largest crowds in CFL history]], which include five regular-season and four Grey Cup games. A single-game record crowd numbering 69,083 attended a game played on September 6, 1977 between the Alouettes and [[Toronto Argonauts]].{{cite web |author = Gouvernement du Québec |title = About the Olympic Park – Facts and figures |publisher = La Régie des installations olympiques |year = 2004 |url = http://www.rio.gouv.qc.ca/pub/parc/statistiques.jsp?locale=en |accessdate = November 22, 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070808052746/http://www.rio.gouv.qc.ca/pub/parc/statistiques.jsp?locale=en |archivedate = August 8, 2007 |df = mdy-all }} In 1991 and 1992, the stadium was the home of the [[Montreal Machine]] of the [[World League of American Football]]. This included hosting [[World Bowl '92]] on June 6, 1992, in which the [[Sacramento Surge]] defeated the [[Orlando Thunder]] 21–17 before 43,789.{{cite web|url=http://www.funwhileitlasted.net/gallery/world-league-of-american-football-1991-1992/programs/1992-world-bowl-sacramento-surge-orlando-thunder/|title=Sacramento Surge vs. Orlando Thunder. World Bowl II. June 6, 1992 • Fun While It Lasted|publisher=|accessdate=November 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201030556/http://funwhileitlasted.net/gallery/world-league-of-american-football-1991-1992/programs/1992-world-bowl-sacramento-surge-orlando-thunder/|archive-date=December 1, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{better source|date=November 2017|reason=as a fan-created site, this does not meet reliable source guidelines}} In 1988 (Jets and Browns) and 1990 (Steelers and Patriots), NFL pre-season games were played at Olympic Stadium.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/07/29/sports/nfl-quebec-welcomes-a-taste-of-the-nfl.html|title=N.F.L.; Quebec Welcomes a Taste of the N.F.L.|date=July 29, 1988|accessdate=October 22, 2013|publisher=[[New York Times]]|last=Eskenazi|first=Gerald}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/jets/2009/12/oh-canada-jets-vs-bills.html|title=Oh, Canada: Jets vs. Bills|date=December 3, 2009|accessdate=October 22, 2013|publisher=[[New York Daily News]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029092250/http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/jets/2009/12/oh-canada-jets-vs-bills.html|archivedate=October 29, 2013|df=mdy-all}} ===Baseball=== [[Image:Stade Olympique Roof.JPG|thumb|right|Detail of the roof including the foul lines]] In 1977, the stadium replaced [[Jarry Park Stadium]] as the home ballpark of the [[National League]]'s [[Montreal Expos]]. As a part of the team's franchise grant, a domed stadium was supposed to be in place for the 1972 baseball season. However, due to the delays in constructing Olympic Stadium, until 1977, the Expos annually sought and received a waiver to remain at Jarry. As late as January 1977, it was thought the Expos would have to play at least part of the 1977 season at Jarry as well. The [[Parti Québécois]]' landslide victory in the [[Quebec general election, 1976|1976 provincial elections]] caused the Expos to break off lease talks. However, an agreement was reached in February, and an official announcement came in March. The Expos regularly played 81 home games every season until [[2003 Montreal Expos season|2003]], when they played 22 home games in [[Puerto Rico]] at [[Hiram Bithorn Stadium]] in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. The Expos played 59 home games at Olympic Stadium in each of their final two seasons of 2003 and 2004; the franchise moved south to Washington, D.C. for the [[2005 Washington Nationals season|2005 season]] and became the [[Washington Nationals]]. Olympic Stadium's first-ever baseball game was played on April 15, 1977. In front of 57,592, the Expos lost 7–2 to the [[Philadelphia Phillies]]. However, the Expos had to use a hacksaw to cut open the locks because the OIB did not have a master key. The Expos played five home playoff games in 1981; two in the [[1981 National League Division Series|NLDS]] against the Phillies, and three in the [[1981 National League Championship Series|NLCS]] against the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], who went on to win the [[1981 World Series|World Series]]. On October 19, the Expos lost the decisive fifth game, 2–1, to the Dodgers on [[Rick Monday]]'s ninth-inning [[home run]]. In 1982, the [[1982 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|Major League Baseball All-Star Game]] was played at Olympic Stadium in front of 59,057—a stadium record for baseball. On September 29, 2004, the Expos played their last game in Montreal, losing 9–1 to the [[Florida Marlins]] before 31,395.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/the-expos-last-home-game-an-oral-history|title=The Expos' last home game: An oral history – Sportsnet.ca|work=Sportsnet.ca|accessdate=May 16, 2016}} [[Image:Toronto Blue Jays vs. New York Mets in Montreal.JPG|thumb|right|700px|Olympic Stadium panoramic during an MLB preseason game in 2014]] Olympic Stadium proved to be somewhat problematic as a baseball venue. As in all multipurpose stadiums, the lower seating tier was set further back than in baseball-specific parks to accommodate the football field. However, since [[Canadian football]] fields are longer and wider than [[American football]] fields, Olympic Stadium's lower tier was set back even further than comparable seats at American multipurpose stadiums.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/worstballparks/010503.html |title=ESPN.com – Page2 – The List: Worst ballparks |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=April 4, 2014}} The upper deck was one of the highest in the majors; as was the case with most of its multipurpose counterparts, most of the upper-deck seats, particularly those in the outfield, were too far away to be of any use during the regular season. The Expos felt considerable chagrin that they were not consulted on the stadium's location, design, or construction even though they were slated to be its primary tenants. Nonetheless, for most of their tenure they put considerable effort into making the atmosphere friendlier for baseball. During the 1970s and early 1980s, fans arriving at the stadium from the [[Montreal Metro|Metro]] were greeted by an [[oom-pah]] band playing "[[The Happy Wanderer]]." Whenever an opposing pitcher tried to hold a runner at first rather than pitch, the sound system would cluck at him like a chicken. Before the [[1991 Montreal Expos season|1991 season]], the OIB began a major overhaul on the stadium's baseball configuration. The lower deck in center field was removed to make room for a larger scoreboard with replay capability.[http://www.andrewclem.com/Baseball/OlympicStadium.html Clem's Baseball Blog] entry on Olympic Stadium That scoreboard was installed ahead of the [[1992 Montreal Expos season|1992 season]]. Also ahead of the 1992 season, the running track was removed, home plate was moved closer to the stands and new seats closer to the field were installed. Several distant sections of permanent seating beyond the outfield fence were closed, replaced with bleacher seats directly behind the fence. The total seating capacity for baseball was reduced from a high of around 60,400 to 46,000. The Expos were very successful in the stadium for a time, with above National League median attendance in 1977 and from 1979 to 1983. The Expos outdrew the [[New York Mets]] from 1977 to 1983, and 1994 to 1996, as well as the [[New York Yankees]] in 1982 and 1983.{{cite web | author = Sports Reference | title = Washington Nationals Attendance, Stadiums and Park Factors | publisher = baseball-reference.com | year = 2008 | url = https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/WSN/attend.shtml | accessdate =September 1, 2008 }} {{cite web | author = Sports Reference | title = New York Mets Attendance, Stadiums and Park Factors | publisher = baseball-reference.com | year = 2008 | url = https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYM/attend.shtml | accessdate =September 1, 2008 }} {{cite web | author = Sports Reference | title = New York Yankees Attendance, Stadiums and Park Factors | publisher = baseball-reference.com | year = 2008 | url = https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYY/attend.shtml | accessdate =September 1, 2008 }} The stadium's playing conditions left much to be desired. For most of the Expos' tenure, the playing surface was an extremely thin [[AstroTurf]] carpet, with only equally thin padding between it and the concrete floor. It was so hard on players' knees that visiting teams frequently ran at a nearby park. Longtime Expos trainer Ron McClain begged for a replacement, but the OIB was unwilling to spend the $1 million needed for a new surface. Before the roof finally arrived, players had to contend with huge patches of ice in early April or late September. Additionally, for most of the Expos' tenure, the padding on the fence was so thin that fielders risked severe injury by going after long fly balls. However, the OIB was also unwilling to replace the padding. By the 1990s, several free agents specifically demanded that the Expos be taken out of consideration due to the poor playing conditions.{{cite book|last=Keri|first=Jonah|title= Up, Up and Away|publisher=[[Random House|Random House Canada]]|location=[[Toronto]]|year=2014|isbn=9780307361356}} By the mid-1990s, owner [[Claude Brochu]] concluded that Olympic Stadium was not suitable as a baseball venue, and actively campaigned for a replacement. Brochu sold the team to [[Jeffrey Loria]] in 2000, who was equally dissatisfied with Olympic Stadium; he bluntly stated, "We cannot stay here." However, [[Premier of Quebec|Quebec Premier]] [[Lucien Bouchard]] refused to authorize public funding deemed necessary for a replacement, in part because Olympic Stadium still had not been paid for.{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Curt |authorlink=Curt Smith (author)|title=Storied Stadiums|year=2001|publisher=Carroll & Company|location=New York City|isbn=0-7867-1187-6}} Ten years after the last Expos game at Olympic Stadium, the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] played two [[spring training]] games at the stadium against the [[New York Mets]] on March 28 and 29, 2014, with combined attendance of 96,350.{{cite web|url=http://www2.tsn.ca/montreal/story/?id=447733 |title=Cabrera's home run in the eighth gives Jays win over Mets |publisher=Tsn.ca |date= |accessdate=March 29, 2014}} The Jays have continued this practice in subsequent years since, against the [[Cincinnati Reds]] on April 3 and 4, 2015, with combined attendance of 96,545,{{cite web|url=http://www.citylab.com/design/2015/04/the-baseball-stadium-montreal-never-built/389859/|title=The Downtown Stadium That Could Have Saved the Montreal Expos|author=Mark Byrnes|work=CityLab|access-date=June 22, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.macleans.ca/culture/96000-fans-show-their-love-of-baseball-at-blue-jays-games-in-montreal/|title=96,000 fans show their love of baseball at Blue Jays games in Montreal|agency=The Canadian Press|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=June 22, 2015}} the [[Boston Red Sox]] on April 1 and 2, 2016, with combined attendance of 106,102,{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/red-sox-top-blue-jays-sweep-two-game-montreal-series/|title=Red Sox top Blue Jays to sweep two-game Montreal series|work=Sportsnet.ca|access-date=May 16, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-to-face-red-sox-in-montreal-next-spring/|title=Blue Jays to face Red Sox in Montreal next spring|work=Sportsnet.ca|access-date=May 16, 2016}} the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] on March 31 and April 1, 2017, combined attendance of 95,382,{{cite web|url=https://jaysjournal.com/2017/03/27/blue-jays-tab-starters-for-upcoming-montreal-series/|title=Blue Jays tab starters for upcoming Montreal series|date=March 27, 2017|publisher=|access-date=November 23, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/baseball/mlb/blue-jays-pirates-montreal-game-recap-1.4051286|title=Blue Jays end pre-season with win in Montreal|publisher=|access-date=November 23, 2017}} and the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] on March 26 and 27, 2018, with combined attendance of 51,151.{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/baseball/cardinals-use-three-run-eighth-inning-to-beat-blue-jays-at-olympic-stadium/article38351513/|title=Cardinals use three-run eighth inning to beat Blue Jays at Olympic Stadium|date=March 26, 2018|publisher=The Globe And Mail|access-date=March 28, 2018}} ====Longest home runs==== [[Willie Stargell]] of the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] hit the longest home run at Olympic Stadium on May 20, 1978, driving the ball into the second deck in right field for an estimated distance of 535 feet. The yellow seat that marked the location where the ball landed has been removed from the 300 level. The seat is now preserved at the [[Canadian Baseball Hall of Fame]]. Stargell also hit a notable home run at the Expos' original Montreal home, Jarry Park, which landed in a swimming pool beyond the right field fence.{{cite web |author = Ballpark Digest |title = Jarry Park / Montreal Expos / 1969–1976 |publisher = Ballpark Digest |url = http://www.ballparkwatch.com/stadiums/past/jarry_park.htm |accessdate = September 22, 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011235631/http://www.ballparkwatch.com/stadiums/past/jarry_park.htm |archivedate = October 11, 2007 |df = mdy-all }} On April 4, 1988, the Expos' Opening Day, [[Darryl Strawberry]] of the [[New York Mets]] hit a ball off a speaker which hangs off a concrete ring at Olympic Stadium, estimated to have traveled 525 feet. [[Henry Rodríguez (outfielder)|"Oh Henry" Rodríguez]] hit a ball on June 15, 1997, that bounced off the concrete ring in right field, caromed up to hit the roof, and came down, hitting a speaker. The distance traveled by this ball is also estimated at 525 feet. The longest home run hit to left field was [[Vladimir Guerrero]]'s blast on July 28, 2003, that hit an advertising sign directly below the left field upper deck. The ad was later replaced with a sign reading "VLAD 502".{{cite book | author=Montreal Expos | authorlink = Montreal Expos | title = Expos Media Guide 2004 | year = 2004}} ===Soccer=== [[Image:Olympic Stadium Soccer.JPG|thumb|right|Olympic Stadium with natural grass field]] The Olympic Stadium was the home of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]]'s [[Montreal Manic]] soccer team from 1981 to 1983. A 1981 playoff game against the [[Chicago Sting]] attracted a crowd of over 58,000. Several games of the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2007]] [[FIFA]] [[FIFA U-20 World Cup|Under 20 World Cup]] were played at Olympic Stadium and drew the largest crowds of the tournament, including two sell-outs of 55,800. Olympic Stadium hosted a [[CONCACAF Champions League]] quarter-final game pitting the [[Montreal Impact (1992–2011)|original Montreal Impact]] – who played primarily in the adjacent [[Saputo Stadium]] – against [[Club Santos Laguna]] of the [[Liga MX]] (Mexico First Division) on February 25, 2009. This was the first time an international soccer game took place in Montreal during the winter months.{{cite web |url=http://www.montrealimpact.com/News/News.aspx?language=EN&ArticleID=1044&Focus=0 |title=News |publisher=Montrealimpact.com |date= |accessdate=March 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930181218/http://www.montrealimpact.com/News/News.aspx?language=EN&ArticleID=1044&Focus=0 |archivedate=September 30, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} The Impact won 2–0 in front of a record crowd of 55,571.{{cite news | first=Sean| last=Farrell| author2= | title=Big Montreal crowd takes in winter soccer| date=February 25, 2009| publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]] | url =https://sports.yahoo.com/sow/news;_ylt=Am1qmutmJ1KMvef.wg56wzgmw7YF?slug=ap-santos-impact&prov=ap&type=lgns| work = | pages = | accessdate =February 25, 2009 | language = }} The stadium was also home to a friendly match between the Impact and [[A.C. Milan]] of the Italian [[Serie A]] on June 2, 2010 before 47,861.{{Cite journal| title =Guess who's coming to town?| date =April 14, 2010| publisher =The Offside| url =http://montreal.theoffside.com/team-news/guess-whos-coming-to-town.html| work =| pages =| accessdate =April 14, 2010| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110717020432/http://montreal.theoffside.com/team-news/guess-whos-coming-to-town.html| archivedate =July 17, 2011| df =mdy-all}} On July 25, 2009, Olympic Stadium became the first stadium outside France to host [[Ligue 1]]'s [[2009 Trophée des Champions|Trophée des Champions]], a [[super cup]] played by the winner of Ligue 1 and the [[Coupe de France]]. Over 34,000 attended the game. [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] defeated [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp,]] 2–0. The game was held in Montreal to help Ligue 1 break into the growing North America soccer market.{{cite web|author=profil Se déconnecter |url=http://www.rds.ca/soccer/le-troph%C3%A9e-des-champions-%C3%A0-montr%C3%A9al-1.217048 |title=Le trophée des champions à Montréal |publisher=RDS.ca |date= |accessdate=June 14, 2013}} On March 17, 2012, a record crowd of 58,912 packed Olympic Stadium to cheer on the current version of the [[Montreal Impact]] for their [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] debut on home soil, in an entertaining 1–1 draw with the [[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire]], setting a new attendance record for professional soccer in Quebec.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/matchcenter/2012-03-17-mtl-v-chi/recap |title=Recap: Record crowd sees Impact tie Fire in home debut |publisher=mlssoccer.com |date=March 17, 2012 |accessdate=September 26, 2013}} That record was later broken on May 12, 2012 with 60,860 people for a match against the [[LA Galaxy]], also setting a new attendance record for professional soccer in Canada.{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/soccer/galaxy-tie-impact-before-record-crowd/article2430996/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | title=Galaxy tie Impact before record crowd | date=June 18, 2012}} On August 24, 2014, the Olympic Stadium hosted the final match of the [[2014 FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/u20womensworldcup/matches/kostage.html |title=FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup: Matches – Knockout stage |publisher=FIFA.com |date= |accessdate=April 4, 2014}} On April 29, 2015, a record crowd of 61,004 attended the final match of the [[CONCACAF Champions League]] between the Montreal Impact and [[Club América]], establishing a new record attendance for professional soccer in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/ccl/news/article/2015/04/28/champions-league-montreal-impact-sell-2000-more-tickets-final-setting-new-ca|title=Champions League: Montreal Impact sell 2,000 more tickets to final, setting new Canadian record|work=MLSsoccer.com|accessdate=June 22, 2015}} The Olympic Stadium hosted tournament matches for the [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup]] along with other stadiums across Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/destination/cities/index.html |title=FIFA Women's World Cup: Destination – Host Cities |publisher=FIFA.com |date= |accessdate=July 14, 2014}} One notable game was the semi-final match-up between the [[United States women's national soccer team|United States]] and [[Germany women's national football team|Germany]] that took place on June 30, 2015, which drew a crowd of 51,176 people. The Americans won 2–0 in front of a largely partisan crowd and then went on to win their record third FIFA Women's World Cup trophy the following Sunday in [[Vancouver]]. This stadium is one of Canada's three candidate venues for the [[2026 FIFA World Cup]] and is expected to get a retractable roof during the renovations for this sports event.{{cite web|url=https://montrealgazette.com/sports/soccer/olympic-stadium-will-have-a-retractable-roof-in-time-for-2026-world-cup|title=Olympic Stadium will have a retractable roof in time for 2026 World Cup|date=June 15, 2018|publisher=Montréal Gazette}} === Office space === Starting in 2018, the [[Desjardins Group]] plans to move approximately 1000 of its employees into the Montreal Tower. The company plans to occupy 7 of the 12 floors available in the tower. It is estimated that around $60 million in renovations are required before Desjardins can move in.{{Cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2564127/desjardins-to-move-into-montreal-olympic-stadium-tower/|title=Desjardins to move into Montreal Olympic Stadium tower|last=Lau|first=Rachel|website=Global News|access-date=April 8, 2016}} ===Other=== Olympic Stadium hosted the 1978 [[World Junior Speed Skating Championships]] where they crowned the American siblings [[Eric Heiden|Eric]] and [[Beth Heiden]] as junior world champions.{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Randy |date=February 6, 1978 |title=Eric, Beth not Heiden in Junior speed skating |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xZAjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U6EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3548%2C1263691 |newspaper=''The Gazette'' |location=Montreal |publisher= |accessdate=August 8, 2014 }} In August 1979 the Olympic Stadium hosted the [[1979 IAAF World Cup|1979 IAAF World Cup in Athletics]]. On June 20, 1980, [[Roberto Durán]] defeated [[Sugar Ray Leonard]] to win the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] welterweight championship at the Olympic Stadium. The [[Drum Corps International]] World Championship finals were held at this arena in 1981 and 1982. On September 11, 1984, [[Pope John Paul II]] participated in a youth rally with about 55,000 people in attendance.{{cite web|url=http://www.americancatholic.org/Features/JohnPaulII/4-Canada-1984.asp |title=The Pope in Canada: A Journey Into the Heart |publisher=Americancatholic.org |date= |accessdate=March 2, 2011}} [[Image:Montreal Stadium full mast.jpg|thumb|right|Full view of the Montreal Olympic Stadium's mast from the side]] [[Image:StadiumTrack.JPG|thumb|right|A view from the upper deck of the monster truck layout]] [[Image:Biodome de Montreal.jpg|thumb|right|[[Montreal Biodome]] in front of Olympic Stadium and its tower]] On October 30, 2010, a special mass, to commemorate the ascension to sainthood of [[André Bessette|Brother André]], was held at the stadium. Over 30,000 people attended.{{cite web|author=Anne Sutherland, Montreal Gazette: Monday, November 1, 2010 |url=http://www.globaltvedmonton.com/faithful+flock+Olympic+Stadium+Brother+Andre+celebration/3758076/story.html |title=30,000 faithful flock to Olympic Stadium for Brother Andre celebration |publisher=Globaltvedmonton.com |date=November 1, 2010 |accessdate=March 2, 2011}} In 2017, the venue was the site of the [[2017 Artistic Gymnastics World Championships]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.flogymnastics.com/article/30225-montreal-confirmed-host-for-2017-artistic-world-championships|title=Montreal Confirmed Host For 2017 Artistic World Championships|website=FloGymnastics|access-date=April 9, 2016}} ===Attendance record=== [[Pink Floyd]] attracted the largest ever paid crowd to the Olympic Stadium: 78,322 people on July 6, 1977. The second-largest crowd was 73,898 for [[Emerson, Lake & Palmer]] on August 26, 1977. The largest crowds for an opera performance were on June 16 and 18, 1988, with 63,000 to watch a production of ''[[Aida]]''.{{cite web|url=http://parcolympique.qc.ca/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/F_assistances_stade.pdf|title=LE STADE OLYMPIQUE|publisher=|accessdate=November 23, 2017}} ==Transit== The stadium is [[Underground City, Montreal|directly connected]] to the [[Pie-IX (Montreal Metro)|Pie-IX metro station]] on the [[Line 1 Green (Montreal Metro)|Green Line]] of the [[Montreal Metro]]. [[Viau (Montreal Metro)|Viau metro station]] on the Green Line is also nearby. ==Facts and figures== *At {{convert|165|m|abbr=on}}, the Olympic Stadium is the world's tallest [[Inclined tower|inclined structure]].{{cite web|url=http://parcolympique.qc.ca/en/the-park/the-montreal-tower/|title=The Montréal Tower|publisher=|accessdate=May 16, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160517160325/http://parcolympique.qc.ca/en/the-park/the-montreal-tower/|archive-date=May 17, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} *Well over its original budget, the stadium ended up costing $770 million to construct. By 2006, the final cost had risen to $1.47 billion when calculating in repairs, modifications and interest paid out. It took 30 years to finally pay off the cost, leading to its nickname of "The Big Owe" (a play on "The Big O").{{cite web|url=http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/s/2003/0422/1542254.html |title=Montreal's house of horrors |first=Jeff |last=Merron |work=[[ESPN.com]] |date=April 22, 2003 |accessdate=July 16, 2015}} *The roof is only {{convert|52|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} above the field of play. As a result, a number of [[batted ball|pop-ups]] and long home runs hit the roof over the years, necessitating the painting of orange lines on the roof to separate foul balls from fair balls. *During their years playing in Olympic Stadium the Expos were one of only two teams not to employ the traditional yellow-painted foul poles with the [[New York Mets]] being the other; Olympic's poles were painted red while the Mets' home, [[Shea Stadium]] (and later [[Citi Field]]), used orange poles. *The Olympic Stadium holds the record for a soccer game attendance in Canada. At the 1976 Summer Olympics [[Football at the 1976 Summer Olympics|soccer final]], 72,000 people witnessed [[East Germany national football team|East Germany]]'s 3–1 win over [[Poland national football team|Poland]]. *A yellow seat on the 300 level commemorated a {{convert|534|ft|m|adj=on}} home run by [[Willie Stargell]] of the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]]. It has since been moved to the Canadian Baseball Hall of Fame. *The Montreal games of the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] were held at Olympic Stadium on a removable Team Pro EF RD surface that was purchased specifically for the tournament.{{cite web |author = Montreal Gazette |authorlink = The Gazette (Montreal) |title = New rug for Olympic Stadium |publisher = Canwest Publishing |date = May 1, 2007 |url = http://www.canada.com/topics/sports/football/cfl/story.html?id=7dc11074-e43b-4242-aee7-4533cbc17fc5&k=96984 |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130118220943/http://www.canada.com/topics/sports/football/cfl/story.html?id=7dc11074-e43b-4242-aee7-4533cbc17fc5&k=96984 |dead-url = yes |archive-date = January 18, 2013 |accessdate = May 12, 2010 }} *For the first time since the Olympic Games in 1976, a natural grass field was installed in the stadium for the [[Montreal Impact (1992–2011)|Montreal Impact]] match versus [[A.C. Milan]] on June 2, 2010.{{cite news|last1=Phillips|first1=Randy|title=Grass is greener on the inside|url=https://www.pressreader.com/canada/montreal-gazette/20100529/295274707602733|accessdate=2 January 2018|work=Montreal Gazette|date=29 May 2010}} *The stadium features a 101,600-watt public address system{{cite web |url=http://www.rio.gouv.qc.ca/pub/salles/salle_stade.jsp |title=RIO – Parc olympique de Montréal :: Salles au Stade olympique :: Location de salles au Stade olympique |publisher=Rio.gouv.qc.ca |date= |accessdate=March 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227075543/http://www.rio.gouv.qc.ca/pub/salles/salle_stade.jsp |archivedate=February 27, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} *The main room of the stadium is the largest in Quebec, at {{convert|43504|m2|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://www.rio.gouv.qc.ca/faq/accueil.jsp?locale=en |title=RIO – Montreal Olympic Park :: Frequently Asked Questions |publisher=Rio.gouv.qc.ca |date= |accessdate=March 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706201731/http://www.rio.gouv.qc.ca/faq/accueil.jsp?locale=en |archivedate=July 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ==Commemorations== As part of the [[Canadian Olympic stamps#1976 Montreal Olympics|commemorative stamps created for the 1976 Olympics]], Canada Post issued a stamp depicting the Olympic Stadium and Velodrome.{{cite web |title = Canadian Stamps Marked Montreal Olympics |author = John Burnett |url = http://www.bnaps.org/education/esc7.asp |accessdate = October 22, 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120620180025/http://www.bnaps.org/education/esc7.asp |archivedate = June 20, 2012 |df = mdy-all }} ==See also== {{Portal bar|Olympics|Baseball|Canadian football|Soccer|Montreal}} * [[List of Canadian Football League stadiums]] * [[Past MLB stadiums|List of Major League Baseball stadiums (Former stadiums / ballparks)]] * [[Olympic Stadium]] * [[List of tallest buildings and structures in the world]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Sources=== * Rémillard, François. ''Montreal architecture: A Guide to Styles and Buildings.'' Montreal: Meridian Press, 1990. ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{official website|http://parcolympique.qc.ca/en/the-park/olympic-stadium/}} – Parc Olympique Quebec * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130916163736/http://parcolympique.qc.ca/en/the-park/the-montreal-tower/ Official Website – Montreal Tower] * [http://www.ballparks.com/baseball/national/olympi.htm Ballparks.com: Olympic Stadium] * [http://football.ballparks.com/CFL/Montreal/index.htm Football Ballparks.com] * [https://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/WSN/attend.shtml Baseball-Reference] – annual Expos attendance and [[Batting Park Factor|park factors]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121019062244/http://www.baseballlibrary.com/baseballlibrary/ballplayers/O/Olympic_Stadium.stm history and notable events] ''Baseball Library'' * [http://assets.espn.go.com/mlb/s/2003/0422/1542317.html Olympic Stadium disaster timeline] ===Multimedia=== * [http://archives.cbc.ca/IDC-1-41-1316-7812/sports/montreal_olympic_games/clip4 CBC Archives] – Clip from 1975 – Stadium architect talks about his design * [http://archives.cbc.ca/IDC-1-41-1316-7926/sports/montreal_olympic_games/clip12 CBC Archives] – A look back on the history of the stadium (1999) * [http://archives.cbc.ca/society/celebrations/topics/100-554/ CBC Archives] – Discussion of building a tower for Montreal {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = [[Summer Olympics]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Pierre Werner Cricket Ground | nickname = | image = | location = rue de l'Alzette, [[Walferdange]], [[Luxembourg]][http://www.optimists.cc/location/default.aspx Location] - Optimists Cricket Club | coordinates = | broke_ground = | opened = 1991 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Optimists Cricket Club]] | operator = [[Optimists Cricket Club]] | surface = Artificial matting on concrete | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Walferdange Cricket Ground | tenants = [[Optimists Cricket Club]]
[[Luxembourg national cricket team|Luxembourg national team]] | seating_capacity = unknown | record = | lighting = No | video = No }} The '''Pierre Werner Cricket Ground''', also known as the '''Walferdange Cricket Ground''', is a [[cricket]] [[cricket ground|ground]] in [[Walferdange]], in central [[Luxembourg]]. It is the premier cricket venue in Luxembourg, being the home ground of the country's top club, the [[Optimists Cricket Club]], which plays in the Belgian Cricket League, and of the [[Luxembourgian cricket team|Luxembourg national team]]. The ground was opened in 1991.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110626144407/http://www.cricketeurope2.net/docs/ECC/BROCHURES/2011Division2.pdf ICC European Championship, 2011, Division 2 brochure, p12] Retrieved 7 October 2011 In 2002 the ground was given its present name to commemorate [[Pierre Werner]] (1913–2002), formerly [[Prime Minister of Luxembourg]] and honorary president of Optimists Cricket Club.''Wisden Cricketers' Almanack'', 2003 edition, p 1569. The ground was established on land donated by the [[Walferdange|Walferdange commune]], adjacent to the [[Alzette]] river. The ground has hosted matches between the [[Luxembourg national cricket team|Luxembourg national team]] and various other teams, including the [[Belgium national cricket team|Belgium national team]] and the [[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]].[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/111/5555_misc.html Other matches played on Pierre Werner Cricket Ground, Walferdange] - CricketArchive. Retrieved 27 May 2011. The heavy use of the ground is illustrated by the programme in 2003, when it "was in use almost every day between mid-April and early October". That year two internationals against France and one against Belgium were played on the ground (though one of the games against France was rained off).''Wisden Cricketers' Almanack'', 2004 edition, p 1440. A six-a-side tournament was hosted in 2007. The ground is the only outdoor venue regularly used for [[cricket in Luxembourg]], with the only other venue being Robert Schuman Oval, located 300m over the French border in [[Évrange]].[http://www.cricket.lu/grounds.html Grounds] - Luxembourg Cricket Federation The ground's pitch is artificial matting on concrete. The ground hosts a one-week junior training academy each July. In 2010 this was attended by forty boys and girls of all ages, who were coached by a Level 3 coach from the UK and benefited from the ground's "excellent facilities".''Wisden Cricketers' Almanack'', 2011 edition, p 1185. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Coord|49.6644|N|6.1276|E|region:LU_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Walferdange]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Luxembourg]] {{Luxembourg-sports-venue-stub}} {{cricket-ground-stub}}

Paralympic Committee]] (IPC)|date=12 March 2010}} | rank = 20 | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 1 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Poland]]''' will send 12 competitors to compete in three disciplines at the '''[[2010 Winter Paralympics]]''' in [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]].[http://www.vancouver2010.com/paralympic-games/athletes/ Athletes : Vancouver 2010 Winter Paralympics], The Official Website of the Vancouver 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games ==Medalists== ===[[Image:Med 3.png]] Bronze=== * [[Katarzyna Rogowiec]] - Cross-country skiing, 15 km Individual Freestyle == Alpine skiing == {{main|Alpine skiing at the 2010 Winter Paralympics}} skiing at the 2010 Winter Paralympics – Men's slalom#Standing|Slalom standing]] |align="center"|1:02.83 |align="center"|33 |align="center"|1:05.42 |align="center"|33 |align="center"|2:08.25 |align="center"|23 |- |[[Alpine skiing at the 2010 Winter Paralympics – Men's giant slalom#Sitting|Giant slalom standing]] |align="center"|1:24.29 |align="center"|31 |align="center"|1:25.73 |align="center"|30 |align="center"|2:50.02 |align="center"|30 |- |rowspan=2|[[Maciej Krezel]] |[[Alpine skiing at the 2010 Winter Paralympics – Men's slalom#Visually Impaired|Slalom visually impaired]] |align="center"|55.16 |align="center"|12 |align="center"|1:01.65 |align="center"|9 |align="center"|1:56.81 |align="center"|'''8''' |- |[[Alpine skiing at the 2010 Winter Paralympics – Men's giant slalom#Visually Impaired|Giant slalom visually Impaired]] |align="center"|1:28.69 |align="center"|13 |align="center"|1:28.97 |align="center"|8 |align="center"|2:57.66 |align="center"|9 |- {{Infobox football club | clubname = Al-Seeb Club
نادي السيب | image = [[Image:seebclub.jpg|300px|Logo]] | fullname = Al-Seeb Club | nickname = '''Sayyid Al-Nawadi'''
(''Master of the Clubs'') | founded = {{Start date and age|1972}}(1 March 1972) | ground = [[Al-Seeb Stadium]]
[[Seeb|Al-Seeb]], [[Al Batinah Region|Al-Batinah]], [[Oman]] | capacity = 14,000 | chairman = {{Flagicon|OMA}} [[Sayyid]] Shihab Tariq | manager = {{Flag icon|SYR}} [[Emad Dahbour]] | league = [[Oman Professional League]] | season = [[2014–15 Oman Professional League|2014–15]] | position = '''14th''' (Relegated) | website = | pattern_la1 = _kuban1314h | pattern_b1 = _kuban1314h | pattern_ra1 = _kuban1314h | pattern_sh1 = _kuban1213h | pattern_so1 = _vaslui1011h | leftarm1 = FEDD37 | body1 = FEDD37 | rightarm1 = FEDD37 | shorts1 = 198137 | socks1 = FEDD37 | pattern_la2 = _kuban1314a | pattern_b2 = _kuban1314a | pattern_ra2 = _kuban1314a | pattern_sh2 = _kuban1213a | pattern_so2 = _kuban1213a | leftarm2 = 198137 | body2 = 198137 | rightarm2 = 198137 | shorts2 = FEDD37 | socks2 = 198137 | pattern_la3 = _grayborder | pattern_b3 = _condivo16_white | pattern_ra3 = _grayborder | pattern_sh3 = _tigres11a | pattern_so3 = _3_stripes_gold | leftarm3 = 989898 | body3 = 989898 | rightarm3 = 989898 | shorts3 = 1952CD | socks3 = 1952CD }} '''Al-Seeb Club''' ({{lang-ar|نادي السيب}}; also known locally as ''Sayyid Al-Nawadi'', or "Master of the Clubs", or just plainly as '''Al-Seeb''') is an [[Football clubs of Oman|Omani sports club]] based in [[Seeb|Al-Seeb]], [[Oman]].{{cite web | url = http://www.national-football-teams.com/club/2971/2013_1/Al_Seeb.html | title = Al-Seeb | publisher = national-football-teams.com}} The club is currently playing in the [[Oman Professional League]], top division of [[Oman Football Association]]. Their home ground is [[Al-Seeb Stadium]]. The stadium is government owned, but they also own their own personal stadium and sports equipment, as well as their own training facilities. ==History== Al-Seeb Club was founded on 3 January 1972 after merging four different small teams (Watan, Butolah, Hilal and Fida) in [[Seeb|Al-Seeb]] area. The four teams agreed after several meetings in between to unite together and form Al-Seeb. The club was officially registered on 26 June 2002. Shihab Bin Tariq is the leader and chairman of Al-Seeb since 1982. He joined the club in 1975 after completing his university studies and then started with the club playing for the [[volleyball]] first team. He also participated in other games such as [[Soccer|football]], [[basketball]] and [[table tennis]]. His father was also a sportsperson as he was a [[Field hockey|hockey]] player and a [[swimmer]]. ==Being a multisport club== Although being mainly known for their football, Al-Seeb Club like many other clubs in Oman, have not only football in their list, but also [[field hockey|hockey]], [[volleyball]], [[Team handball|handball]], [[basketball]], [[badminton]] and [[squash (sport)|squash]]. They also have a youth football team competing in the Omani Youth league. ==Crest and colours== Al-Seeb Club have been known since establishment to wear a full [[yellow]] or [[green]] (Away) [[Kit (association football)|kit]] (usually a darker shade of yellow or green). They have also had many different sponsors over the years. As of now, [[Adidas]] provides them with kits. ==Honours and achievements== ===National titles=== *'''[[Omani League]]: (0)''' :*Runners-up: [[1994–95 Omani League|1994–95]] *'''[[Sultan Qaboos Cup]]: (3)''' :*Winners: [[1996 Sultan Qaboos Cup|1996]], [[1997 Sultan Qaboos Cup|1997]], [[1998 Sultan Qaboos Cup|1998]] :*Runners-up: [[2003 Sultan Qaboos Cup|2003]], [[2005 Sultan Qaboos Cup|2005]] *'''[[Oman Professional League Cup]]: (1)''' :*Winners: [[2007 Omani Federation Cup|2007]] :*Runners-up: [[2013 Oman Professional League Cup|2013]] *'''[[Oman Super Cup]]: (0)''' :*Runners-up: 1999, 2004 *'''[[Sultan Qaboos Cup|Sultan Qaboos Cup (U-19)]]: (3)''' :*Winners: 1998, 2003, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008 :*Runners-up: [[2003 Sultan Qaboos Cup|2003]], [[2005 Sultan Qaboos Cup|2005]] *'''[[Oman Youth League (U-16)]]: (0)''' :*Runners-up: 1989–90, 2003–04 *'''[[Oman Youth League (U-16)|Oman Youth League (U-16) – Muscat]]: (2)''' :*Winners: 1991–92, 2003–04 :*Runners-up: 1989–90, 1992–93 ===Honours and achievements (Other Sports)=== '''Hockey''' *'''Sultan Qaboos Cup''' (7): :*Winners 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1996, 1997 :*Runners-up 1995 *'''Oman Hockey Premier League''' (3): :*Winners 1993, 1994, 1995 :*Runners-up 1996 *'''National Youth Championship (U-16)''' (2): :*Winners 1990–91, 1991–92 :*Runners-up 1992–93 '''Table Tennis''' *'''National Championship''' (1): :*Winners 1994–95 '''Basketball''' *'''National Championship''' (4): :*Winners 1987–88, 2000–2001, 2003–04, 2007–08 :*Runners-up 1986–87, 1988–89, 1989–90, 1992–93, 1993–94, 1994–95, 1995–1996, 1998–99, 2002–03, 2004–05, 2005–06 *'''National Youth Championship (U-16)''' (1): :*Winners 1995–96 :*Runners-up 1994–95 *'''National Youth Championship (U-16)''' (0): :*Runners-up 1990–91, 1995–96 '''Handball''' *'''National Championship''' (2): :*Winners 2006–2007, 2007–08 :*Runners-up 1988–89, 1999–00, 2001–02, 2002–03, 2003–04, 2005–06 *'''National Youth Championship (U-16)''' (0): :*Runners-up 1988–89, 1990–91 '''Volleyball''' *'''National Championship''' (7): :*Winners 1988–89, 1989–1990, 1990–91, 1993–94, 1995–96, 1996–97, 2007–08 :*Runners-up 1987–88, 1991–92, 2007–08 ==Club performance-International Competitions== ===AFC competitions=== *'''[[Asian Club Championship]]: 2 appearances''' :*[[1995 Asian Club Championship|1995]] : First Round *'''[[Asian Cup Winners' Cup]]:
